other_names: Swinging Posture, Pendant Pose, Lol Asan, Lola Asana, Uthitapadmasana, Uthitta/ Uthita-Padma Asana, Uthit padm Asan
pose_description: Lolasana (Pendant Pose) is a beginning arm balance that presents an experience requiring courage: the courage necessary to literally pull yourself up off the floor.
pose_steps:
1) Start from Padmasana and bring the hands to the floor on the outside of the thighs.
2) Inhale and press down into the palms as you engage the abdomen and lift the legs and buttocks off the floor.
3) Take several breaths and release.
pose_release: 1) To release, come back to the padmasana position loose your legs and relax.
pose_benefits:
1) Strengthens the abdominal muscles and the arms.
2) Lolasana builds awareness in the core of the body. 
3) It helps to build abdominal and arm strength while encouraging usage of uddiyan bandh.
pose_precautions: 1) Not for the persons who have recent or chronic wrist or back injury.

other_names: Wind-freeing Posture, Wind releaving Pose, knee Squeeze Posture, Pavan or Pawan Mukt Asan, Pavana or Pawana Mukta Asana, Pawanmuktasana
pose_description: In Sanskrit “Pavan” means air, “mukta” means release or free. Pavanmuktasana balances the wind in whole body.
pose_steps:
1) Lie on your back. Hug your knees into your chest, while you keep your head, neck and shoulders relaxed and on the floor.
2) Breathe normal.
3) Focus: Close your eyes or gaze beyond your knees and relax your back muscles.
4) Hold the posture for as long as it feels good. 
4)  Practice this posture after backbends to release the muscles.
pose_release:
1) While inhaling release both the legs.
2) One must rest before repeating the exercise.
pose_benefits:
1) This posture releases the muscles of the lower back and relaxes the body.
2) This-asana regulates wind in the body.
3) It relieves constipation and indigestion.
4) It reduces obesity and excessive fat of the abdomen.
5) It helps in keeping away the disease of the lungs and the heart.
6) For people suffering from wind trouble, acidity and gas formation, it has an 
7) instant corrective effect.
8) It is also useful in the treatment of impotence, sterility and menstrual problems.
pose_precautions: 1) Pregnant women should not perform this asana.People with serious back conditions, such as sciatica and slipped disc should avoid this asana.

other_names: Full Snake Posture, Cobra Pose, Serpent, Samp Asan
pose_description: This is a basic yoga posture. It is very easy to do especially if your back is not too stiff and rigid. Regular practice of this asana makes child birth easy, good for digestion and constipation and gives a good blood circulation.
pose_steps:
1) Lie down on the floor with your legs together and your palms down under your shoulders and rest your forehead on the floor.
2) Your elbows should touch your middle portion of the body.
3) Inhale, and raise the head and chest above the navel area, upwards.
3) Tighten the legs from the waist down to the toes.
4) Hold your breath and retain in the same position for a while
pose_release:
1) Exhale, and simultaneously lower the head towards the floor.
2) Relax your body and rest with your right or left cheek on the floor for about 6 seconds.
pose_benefits:
1) This asana brings a rich blood supply to the spinal region and increases flexibility.
2) Energizes and activates the upper areas of the body like head, face, neck, shoulders and chest, and gives the youthful appearance.
3) Good for troubles like constipation, indigestion and it increases appetite.
pose_precautions:
1) Not for the people who are suffering from peptic ulcer, hernia or hyperthyroid.
2) Do not practice cobra asana while pregnancy.

other_names: Full Locust Posture/ Pose, Purna Shalabha or Salabha Asana, Puran Shalabh or Purn Salabh Asan
pose_description: Purna-Salabhasana is a reverse posture to the Cobra Posture, which gives a backward bend to the spine. Values of certain asanas are maximised when done one after the other.
pose_steps:
1) Lie face down on the floor on your stomach, hands stretched backwards close to the body and the legs straight. 
2) Making fists of the hands bring them together beneath the thighs with the wrists touching.
3) Inhale as much air as you can. 
4) Holding your breath make your head straight and put the chin on the floor (on a folded blanket or towel). 
5) Tighten both the legs and lift them up as high as you can. 
6) Do not bend the knees.
7) Remain in the same posture for a few seconds.
8) Exhale and simultaneously lower the legs slowly to the floor. 
9) Do not drop the legs. 
10) By the time the legs touch the floor you should finish exhaling. 
11) You have completed one round of a most strenuous posture.
pose_release:
1) Stay for 30 seconds to 1 minute, then release with an exhalation.
2) Take a few breaths and repeat 1 or 2 times more if you like.
pose_benefits:
1) Strengthens the muscles of the spine, buttocks, and backs of the arms and legs.
2) Stretches the shoulders, chest, belly, and thighs.
3) Improves posture.
4) Stimulates abdominal organs.
5) Helps relieve stress.
pose_precautions:
1) Not for the persons who have following porblems:Headache
2) Serious back injury
3) People with neck injuries should keep their head in a neutral position by looking down at the floor; they might also support the forehead on a thickly folded blanket.

other_names: Paschimotanasana, Back-stretching Posture, seated forward bend pose, Pashchim Uttan Asan, Pashchima Uttana Asana, Paschimottana
pose_description: Literally translated as "intense stretch of the west," Paschimottanasana can help a distracted mind unwind.
pose_steps:
1) From Staff Pose - Dandasana bring the arms straight out to the sides and up over your head.
2) Inhale and draw the spine up long.
3) As you exhale, begin to come forward, hinging at the hips.
4) On each inhale, extend the spine and on each exhale come a bit further into the forward bend.
5) Keep the neck the natural extension of the spine.
6) Do not round the back.
7) Take hold of the ankles or shins, whichever you can reach.
pose_release:
1) Stay in the pose anywhere from 1 to 5 minutes. 
2) To come up, release the hands, straighten the elbows and lift the torso away from the thighs, inhale and lift the torso up in a flat back by pulling the tailbone down and into the pelvis and engaging the abdominal muscles
pose_benefits:
1) Calms the brain and helps relieve stress and mild depression.
2) Stretches the spine, shoulders and hamstrings.
3) Stimulates the liver, kidneys, ovaries, and uterus.
4) Improves digestion.
5) Helps relieve the symptoms of menopause and menstrual discomfort.
6) Soothes headache and anxiety and reduces fatigue.
7) Therapeutic for high blood pressure, infertility, insomnia, and sinusitis. 
8) Traditional texts say that Paschimottanasana increases appetite, reduces obesity, and cures diseases.
pose_precautions:
1) Not for the people who have the problem of asthma and diarrhea.
2) Back injury: Only perform this pose under the supervision of an experienced teacher.

other_names: The Moon Pose, Hare Posture, Shashanka-Asana, Shashank-Asan, Sasankasana, Sasank
pose_description: Shashanka' in Sanskrit means the moon, that’s why it is called moon pose also.
pose_steps:
1) Sit with legs folded backwards, heels apart, knees and toes together (sit in vajrasana).
2) Adjust your hips between the heels (Vajrasana). 
3) Slowly raise your arms over the head.
4) While exhaling, slowly bend forward and stretch your palms on the floor with abdomen pressing against the thighs.
5) Then bring your face downwards and touch the floor with the forehead without raising the buttocks. 
6) Inhaling slowly, return to an upright position, and then reverse the process
pose_release:
1) To release, slowly revert to the normal position of Vajrasana. 
2) You may do this asana at least 8 to 10 times.
pose_benefits:
1) This asana stretches the rectus muscle of the abdomen and helps in improving the digestion.
2) It also relieves constipation and benefits people with sciatica and hypertension.
pose_precautions:
1) Do not release the ankles from their position, without raising the back.
2) Not for the people who are suffering from pain in the hip joint.

other_names: Bridge Posture/ Pose, Setu Bandh Sarvang Asan, Bandha Sarvanga Asana
pose_description: Setu" means bridge. "Bandha" is Lock, and "Asana" is Pose or Posture. "Setu Bandhasana" means construction of a bridge.
pose_steps:
1) Lie in Supine pose (Shavasana) on the floor. Bend your knees and set your feet on the floor, heels as close to the sitting bones possible.
2) Exhale and, pressing your inner feet and arms actively into the floor, push your tailbone upward toward the pubis, firming (but not hardening) the buttocks, and lift the buttocks off the floor. 
3) Keep your thighs and inner feet parallel. 
4) Clasp the hands below your pelvis and extend through the arms to help you stay on the tops of your shoulders.
5) Lift your buttocks until the thighs are about parallel to the floor. 
6) Keep your knees directly over the heels, but push them forward, away from the hips, and lengthen the tailbone toward the backs of the knees. 
7) Lift the pubis toward the navel.Lift your chin slightly away from the sternum and, firming the shoulder blades against your back, press the top of the sternum toward the chin. Firm the outer arms, broaden the shoulder blades, and try to lift the space between them at the base of the neck (where it's resting on the blanket) up into the torso.
pose_release: 1) Stay in the pose anywhere from 30 seconds to 1 minute. Release with an exhalation, rolling the spine slowly down onto the floor.
pose_benefits:
1)Stretches the chest, neck, and spine.
2) Calms the brain and helps alleviate stress and mild depression.\3) Stimulates abdominal organs, lungs, and thyroid.
4) Rejuvenates tired legs.
5) Improves digestion.
6) Helps relieve the symptoms of menopause.
7) Relieves menstrual discomfort when done by support.
8) Reduces anxiety, fatigue, backache, headache, and insomnia.
9) Therapeutic for asthma, high blood pressure, osteoporosis, and sinusitis.
pose_precautions:
1) Neck injury: avoid this pose unless you are practicing under the supervision of an experienced teacher.
2) If necessary, place a thickly folded blanket under your shoulders to protect your neck.

other_names: Skull Shining Breath, Frontal Brain Purification, Kapal-Bhati, Kapal-Bharti
pose_description: The word kapalbhati is made up of two words, kapal meaning skull and bhati means shining, illuminating. Due to the process, the organs under the skull mainly the brain and the small brain are influenced in a good manner.
pose_steps:
1) Keep breathing gradually while sitting in Padmasana .
2) Inhale and start performing Kapalbhati as stated before, that means a strong Rechaka, natural Pooraka and again strong Rechaka and natural pooraka.
3) Keep on doing this rotation swiftly in rhythmic manner.
4) Perform as many cycles as possible and then keep breathing gradually. 
5) All these processes are included under one cycle of Kapalbhati.
pose_benefits: 1) Helps in cleansing, invigorating, warming, prevents illness and allergies.
pose_precautions:
1) The level of common person can go up to 200 repetitions. It is not advisable to increase the number beyond that.
2) Patients suffering from heart trouble, lung trouble should practice this under an expert guidance.
3) Those suffering from diseases of blood circulation should perform the process very carefully.
4) They should perform the process under the guidance and care of experts.

other_names: Vajrasana, Muktasana, Perfect (Perfected) Posture, Perfect Pose, Adept's posture, Gupta Pose, Accomplished Posture, Sidha Mukta Vajra Asana
pose_description: One of the most popular meditation postures is Siddhasana. The Sanskrit name means "Perfect Pose," because one attains perfection in yoga by meditating in this position. Siddhasana is useful to learn, since it is used as the practice seat for some of the pranayamas and the mudras.
pose_steps:
1) Sit down with both legs outstretched.
2) Bend the left knee and place the sole of the left foot against the right thigh so that the heel touches the perineum.
3) Bend the right knee and put the right heel against the public bone.
4) Keep hands with palms open if done between sunrise and sunset; otherwise reverse the palms.
5) The spine should always be held erect.
pose_release: 1) To exit, slide the right foot forward off the left foot, straighten the right leg and do the same with the left leg, returning back into dandasana.
pose_benefits:
1) Siddhasana directs the energy from the lower psychic centers upward through the spine, stimulating the brain and calming the entire nervous system.
2) Redirects blood circulation to the lower spine and abdomen, toning the lumbar region of the spine, the pelvis and the abdominal organs, and balancing the reproductive system and blood pressure.
3) Stabilizes and sublimates sexual energy because of the position of the feet with respect to the genitals.
pose_precautions:
1) Siddhasana should not be practiced by those with sciatica.
2) For men who are interested in maintaining sexual relations (ie. with no long term commitment to celibacy), use a soft sitting support to lift the genitals high enough so that the base of the penis is not compressed.
3) Take care to situate the heels perfectly in the midline.

other_names: Sirsasana, Sirshasana, Sirshasana, Headstand Posture, pole posture Pose, Topsy-turvy Posture, Vipreet Karni Asan/ Mudra
pose_description: This pose is the most recognized yoga pose than the other poses. Standing on one’s head is called Sirsasana. It is also called the king of the asanas, so one can practice this asana after having mastery in other asanas.
pose_steps:
1) Firstly kneel down on the mat. 
2) Then interlock the fingers of your hands and place them and your forearms on the extra padding on the yoga mat.
3) Keep your elbows close together. 
4) Place the back of your head into the hollow of the palms.
5) Now, rise up off your knees and take a step or two towards the head.
6) Inhale, and slowly raise the legs until they are vertical.
7) Now, keep your back straight and try to relax and breathe deeply and slowly from the abdomen.
8) Now, concentrate on the brain or the pineal gland between the eyebrows.
pose_release:
1) To release or to come down, bend your knees and lower one leg and then the other.
2) For the beginners, just ask your friend to hold one of your legs while you lower the other leg.
pose_benefits:
1) It promotes hair growth by increasing blood circulation in the scalp.
2) The Shirshasana or the headstand increases the circulation to the brain, due to which we can have improved brain functions and increased vitality and confidence.
3) Poor blood circulation, fear, sleeplessness, headache, tension, constipation and the problems of eyes and nose can be improved by it.
4) It also helps to put the spine into correct alignment.
pose_precautions:
1) Not for the persons who have high or low blood pressure, atherosclerosis (blocked blood vessels), any history of strokes, serious eye disease, pus in ears, suffering from constipation, suffering from neck injury, or also who have organically defective pituitary.
2) But after recovering from these diseases you can try do this asana.

other_names: Shoulder Stand, Viprita Karni Asan/ Mudra, Viprit Karani Mudra, Saravanga
pose_description: This mysterious Asana which gives wonderful benefits. In this Asana the whole weight of the body is thrown on the shoulders. You really stand on the shoulders with the help and support of the elbows. Concentrate on the Thyroid gland which lies on the front lower part of the neck.
pose_steps:
1) Lie on the back quite flat. Slowly raise the legs.
2) Lift the trunk, hips, and legs quite vertically.
3) Support the back with the two hands, one on either side.
4) Rest the elbows on the ground. 
5) Press the chin against the chest (Jalandhara Bandha).
6) Allow the back-shoulder portion and neck to touch the ground closely.
7) Do not allow the body to shake or move to and fro. Keep the legs straight.
pose_release: 1) To release, bring the legs down very, very slowly with elegance and not with any jerks.
pose_benefits:
1) It brightens the psychic faculties and awakens Kundalini Sakti, removes all sorts of diseases of intestine and stomach, and augments the mental power.
2) It supplies a large quantity of blood to the roots of spinal nerves.
3) It is this Asana which centralises the blood in the spinal column and nourishes it beautifully.
pose_precautions:
1) Pregnancy: If you are experienced with this pose, you can continue to practice it late into pregnancy. 
2) However, don't take up the practice of Sarvangasana after you become pregnant.
3) Not for the persons who have the problem of diarrhea, headache, high blood pressure, menstruation, neck injury.

other_names: Prone Fish Posture/ Pose, Adho Matsya Asana, Adha Matsy Asan
pose_description: In this asana posture the shape of the body appears similar to fish in the water. Such a statement is bold, as the fact is, we don't recognize the posture as fish but one can float on the water without any movement in this asana.
pose_steps:
1) Lie down on the ground on your back in shavasana .
2) Now, keep your buttocks on the floor, inhale and raise the head, shoulder, back and the upper arms off the floor arching the back and raising the chest up.
3) Tilt your head back and place the top of the head flat on the ground.
4) Now, raise your elbows off the floor and bring your hands up just below your chest and join them at the palms with the fingers pointing straight up (or we can say, in Anjali mudra).
5) Then breathe gently through the nostrils to remain longer in the pose.
pose_release: 1) When you think it’s enough for you or you feel tired then come back to shavasana.
pose_benefits:
1) This asana increases the size of the rib cage.
2) Make the neck flexible and strong.
3) It widens the wind pipe and thus helps deep breathing.
4) Good effects on the facial tissue.
5) Correct the disorders of the spine.
pose_precautions:
1) This asana can also be tried with padamasana but the beginners should not do this with padamasana because first one will be easier for the beginners.
2) The persons who have migraine, high or low blood pressure and serious neck or back injury.

other_names: Half spinal twist Posture, Half lord of the fishes Pose, Ardho Matseyanrasana, Adha Matsynder Asan
pose_description: This Asana in its original form is difficult to practice, therefore, it was simplified which is called 'Ardha-Matsyendrasana'. After sufficient practice of this Asana, it becomes possible to practice Matsyendrasana.
pose_steps:
1) Sit down on the floor with your legs straight out in front of you and buttocks on the floor.
2) Bend the right leg at the knee and place the heel tight at the perineum.
3) Keep the foot of the left leg by the side of the right thigh near the knee.
4) Now, bring the right hand round the outer side of the left knee passing between the chest and the knee and catch hold of the left big toe.
5) The right shoulder blade rests on the outer side of the left knee.
6) Take the left hand round the back and try to catch the right thigh. 
7) Now look back over the left shoulder.
8) Now, keep your trunk in vertical position and keep in the pose for a while.
pose_release:
1) Release the position with an exhalation.
2) Then come back to the starting position.
pose_benefits:
1) It stimulates the digestive fire in the stomach.
2) Energises the spine and make it flexible.
3) It relieves the menstrual discomfort, fatigue, and backache.
4) Also stimulates the liver and kidney and stretches neck, shoulders, and hips.
5) Helps to cure constipation and reduces the abdominal girth.
pose_precautions: 1) Not for the persons who have spine or back injury.

other_names: The Supine Vajrasana, Pelvic Posture, Fixed Firm Pose, Supta-Vajra-Asana, Supt-Vajr-Asan
pose_description: his asana is the further development of Vajrasana. 'Supta' in Sanskrit means supine and Vajrasana means lying on the back. We lie on our back with folded legs, hence, it is called Supta-Vajrasana.
pose_steps:
1) Lie in Supine pose (Shavasana) on the floor. 
2) Bend your knees and set your feet on the floor, heels as close to the sitting bones possible.
3) Exhale and, pressing your inner feet and arms actively into the floor, push your tailbone upward toward the pubis, firming (but not hardening) the buttocks, and lift the buttocks off the floor. 
4) Keep your thighs and inner feet parallel. 
5) Clasp the hands below your pelvis and extend through the arms to help you stay on the tops of your shoulders.
6) Lift your buttocks until the thighs are about parallel to the floor. 
7) Keep your knees directly over the heels, but push them forward, away from the hips, and lengthen the tailbone toward the backs of the knees. 
8) Lift the pubis toward the navel.
9) Lift your chin slightly away from the sternum and, firming the shoulder blades against your back, press the top of the sternum toward the chin. 
10) Firm the outer arms, broaden the shoulder blades, and try to lift the space between them at the base of the neck (where it's resting on the blanket) up into the torso.
pose_release:
1) While returning to the original position, first take out your hands and place it by the side of your body.
2) Now, with the help of elbows sit as in the first position.
pose_benefits:
1) This stretches the thigh muscles and the abdomen.
2) The stomach is stimulated.
3 It strengthens the thighs.
4) Helps those suffering from constipation.
5) It helps to cure sciatica.
pose_precautions: 1) There should never be more than normal pressure on the back, arms, and the ankle joints while doing this exercise.

other_names: Bow Posture, Bow pose, Dhanur Asana, Bowposture
pose_description: This asana actually looks a lot like an archer’s bow when you are in full pose. This is a pose best done after a little warm-up with other poses. It may be difficult for beginners. Bhujangasana, or cobra pose, is a nice pose to start building up the strength required in bow posture.
pose_steps:
1) Lie down on your stomach.
2) Bend your knees and hold the ankles.
3) Inhale and pull your hands and push with your legs, knees together, till the trunk forms an arc shape with only the stomach on the ground.
4) Look up and remain in the position for a while.
pose_release:
1) Retain breath and then exhale and lie flat.
2) After releasing, lie in shavasan for a while.
pose_benefits:
1)It reduces abdominal fat.
2) The compressing of the spinal column, pressing the nerves with the scapulae (The winged bones at the back attached to the arms) minimizes blood circulation while in the asan.
3) When the pose is released a greater supply of blood is endured to those very regions increasing spinal flexibility and definitely raising the vitality. 
4) Good for gastrointestinal, constipation, upset stomach, sluggish liver.
pose_precautions:
1) Not for persons suffering from peptic ulcer, hernia, or cases of thyroid or endocrine gland disorders.
2) Do not try to stay in position if you are feeling too much pain.

other_names: Cat Pose, Billi Posture, Majra Asana, Majr Asan
pose_description: Cat Pose or Majrasana teaches you to initiate movement from your center and to coordinate your movements and breath. These are two of the most important themes in asana practice.
pose_steps:
\1) Crouch down, on all fours, like a cat; knees hip width apart, hands shoulder width apart, under your shoulders. Arms remain straight.
2)Loosen your spine by contracting the abdominal muscles during exhalation, rounding your back towards the ceiling, tucking the tail-bone in and lowering the head with chin towards your chest.
3) Inhaling, release the contraction, tip the tail bone upwards, dip your spine towards the floor and raise your head. 
4) Expand your chest and complete inhalation.
5) Alternate these positions several times, coordinating the movements with your breath.
pose_release: 1) To release, Come back to the first posture and then relax in a comfortable posture.
pose_benefits:
1) This pose will increase the suppleness of your spine, relieve tension in the back and neck area, firm the abdominal muscles and tones internal abdominal organs. 
2) It is a great counterpoise for back bends and exercises the pelvic floor.
3) The cat pose also benefits people with asthma or heart problems as it expands the lungs.
pose_precautions: 1) If you have weak wrists, make fists and put your knuckles on the floor, thumbs forward.

other_names: Cow Face Posture, Cow head Pose, Gomukh Asan, Gomukha Asana
pose_description: This asana resembles the face of the cow that’s why it is called the 'cow face' or 'gomukhasana'.
pose_steps:
1) From Knee to Ankle, slide the knees to center stacking the right knee directly over the left.
2) It may be helpful to come forward onto the hands and knees to align the knees.
3) Then separate the feet and come back to sit between the feet.
4) Bring the left arm up towards the ceiling.
5) Bend the left elbow, bringing the left hand down the center of the back.
6) Bring the right arm out to the right side, bend the elbow and bring the right arm up the center of the back.
7) Hold hands behind the back.
8) Draw both elbows toward the center.
pose_release: 1) Hold the position for four to eight breaths and then come back to the relaxed posture.
pose_benefits: 1) It stretches the ankles, hips and thighs, shoulders, armpits and triceps, and chest.
pose_precautions: 1) Not for the persons who have serious neck, shoulder or knee problems.

other_names: Bow To the Ear Pose, Bow And Arrow Posture, Akarn-Dhanushtankara, Karna-Dhanurasana, Akarna-Dhanush-Tankara Asana
pose_description: In this asana the body is stretched more like a string of bow when pulled at the time of archery.
pose_steps:
1) Bend the left leg in knee and keep the foot on the thigh of right leg. 
2) Keep the right leg straight.
3) Hold the big toe of the left leg with right hand; hold it between the thumb and index finger and other 3 fingers to have a good grip of the thumb. 
4) Hold big toe of the right leg with left hand.
5) Exhale and inhaling start lifting the left foot with the right hand and pull it up to ear. 
6) Keep the trunk and neck erect and the sight fixed on the other end of the left hand.
7) Continue normal breathing.
pose_release:
1) Inhale and exhaling, start bringing the foot down and place it on the thigh.
2) Restore the hands to their place.
3) Take the left foot to original position.
pose_benefits:
1) In this asana great strain is exerted on hand, legs and joints of waist and the knees. 
2) Consequently the efficiency of the organs increases.
pose_precautions: 1) One should avoid the temptation of attaining the ideal position if strain is unbearable.

other_names: Circle Pose, Full Wheel Posture, Full circle, Purna Chakra Asan, Puma Chakrasana, Up-ward Bow Posture, Back-bend Pose
pose_description: Chakrasana is the most important and fundamental backbend. In this pose, you have to lie on your back and push up, balancing just on the hands and feet. This pose is called a bridge. A back limber is a skill in which the pose is achieved by bending backward from a standing position.
pose_steps:
1) Lie facing upward on the floor.
2) Bend your knees and set your feet on the floor, heels as close to the sitting bones as possible.
3) Bend your elbows and spread your palms on the floor beside your head. 
4) Forearms relatively perpendicular to the floor, fingertips pointing towards shoulders.
5) While inhaling, slowly begin to raise the head, back and buttocks off the floor while arcing the spine.
6) Hold for the duration of the held inhaled breath.
pose_release:
1) When you can’t hold the breath comfortable any longer, slowly exhale and return the back to the floor.
2) Slide the legs out straight returning to the shavasan.
pose_benefits:
1) Strengthens the arms, wrists, buttocks, abdomen and spine.
2) Stretches the lungs and chest. 
3) Stimulates the thyroid and pituitary.
4) Increases energy and counteracts depression.
5) Therapeutic for asthma, back pain, infertility and osteoporosis.
pose_precautions: 1) Not for the persons, who have back injury, carpel tunnel and syndrome, diarrhoea, headache, heart problems, high or low blood pressure.

other_names: Full spinal twist Posture, Full lord of the fishes Pose, Matseyanrasana, Matsynder Asan
pose_description: It is a very powerful asana of yoga. In this asana the body is twisted from a sitting position. The twisting of the spine touches on the basic foundation and functioning of the skeleton itself. A flexible mind and an inflexible spine can rarely be found together.
pose_steps:
1) Sit on the floor with your legs straight out in front of you, buttocks can be supported on a folded blanket.
2) Step the right foot over the left leg and stand it on the floor outside your left hip. 
3) The right knee will point directly up at the ceiling.
4) Exhale and twist toward the inside of the right thigh. 
5) Press the right hand against the floor just behind your right buttock, and set your left upper arm on the outside of your right thigh near the knee. 
6) Pull your front torso and inner right thigh snugly together.
7) Press the inner right foot very actively into the floor, lengthen through the body and continue to lengthen the tailbone into the floor. 
8) Continue the twist of the torso by turning it to the right.
9) With every inhalation lift a little more through the sternum, pushing the fingers against the floor to help.
10) Twist a little more with every exhalation.
11) Be sure to distribute the twist evenly throughout the entire length of the spine; don't concentrate it in the lower back, i.e. right shoulder rolling back as the left shoulder rolls forward.
pose_release: 1) Stay for 30 seconds to 1 minute, then release with an exhalation, return to the starting position, and repeat to the left for the same length of time.
pose_benefits:
1) It stimulates the pancreas, liver, spleen, kidneys, stomach and ascending and descending colons. 
2) It is useful in the treatment of diabetes, constipation, dyspepsia and urinary problems.
3) It tones the nerve roots, and adjusts and realigns the vertebral column. 
4) The back muscles are pulled and stretched in a different direction than usual and this relieves them of tension.
5) Therefore this asana is recommended in the cases of lumbago, rheumatism and slipped disc.
6) In fact, it is a powerful yoga asana and its vitalizing effects can be felt quickly.
pose_precautions:
1) Women more than 2 or 3 months pregnant should avoid this practice.
2) People suffering from peptic ulcer, hernia or hyperthyroidism should only practice this pose under expert guidance.
3) People with sciatica or slipped disc may benefit from this asana, but great care should be taken.

other_names: Lotus Posture/ Pose, Padm Asan, Padma Asana
pose_description: Padma literally means lotus. This is the posture for meditation. It is the ultimate yoga pose, Padmasana requires open hips and consistent practice.
pose_steps:
1) Keep the right foot on the left thigh.
2) Start bouncing the right knee.
3) If the bouncing knee easily touches the floor, then bend the left knee, take hold of the left foot with both hands, gently glide it over the crossed right leg and place it on the right thigh.
4) This will give symmetrical placement of the legs and you are in lotus position.
5) The hands should be kept on the knees with palms open, and the thumb and second finger of each hand should touch forming a letter O.
pose_release: 1) Stay in the position as long as you can and after that release the pose and be comfortable.
pose_benefits:
1) It is effective for liver disorder.
2) This is an extremely good pose for meditation and concentration.
3) It has a calming effect on the mind and the nerves.
4) This pose keeps the spine erect.
5) Helps develop a good posture.
6) Helps keep the joints in flexible condition.
pose_precautions:
1) Those suffering from chronic knee pain should not practice it.
2) Those getting cramps in calf-muscles should practice it cautiously.
3) After keeping one leg on the other thigh, if other leg can not be placed fully on the other thigh, do not try to put it forcefully.

other_names: Lion Posture, Tiger Pose, Singh Asan, Singa or Singha Asana, Sinhasana
pose_description: Placing the palms on the knees, spreading out the fingers (and) opening the mouth wide, one should gaze at the tip of the nose and be well (composed). This Simhasana, adored by ancient yogis.
pose_steps:
1) Sit in Vajrasana .
2) Now raise your buttock a little and cross the heel and toes of the right leg over that of left leg.
3) Sit on the heels and place both hands on the respective knees. 
4) Spread out the fingers.
5) Bring out the tongue as much as possible. Gaze should be on Nasal.
pose_release: 1) While returning back to the original position, take the tongue in, release the tension, loosen your hands and come back to the original position.
pose_benefits:
1) Relieves tension in the chest and face.
2) An often-overlooked benefit of Simhasana is that it stimulates the platysma, a flat, thin, rectangular-shaped muscle on the front of the throat. The platysma, when contracted, pulls down on the corners of the mouth and wrinkles the skin of the neck. 
3) Simhasana helps keep the platysma firm as we age.
4) According to traditional texts, Simhasana destroys disease and facilitates the three major bandhas (Mula, Jalandhara, Uddiyana).
pose_precautions: 1) If you have a knee injury, always be cautious in flexed-knee sitting positions and, if necessary, sit on a chair to do the pose.

other_names: Hand to Foot Pose, Foot to hand Forward Bend Posture, Standing Forward bend, Jackknife Pose, Padahastasana, Hasta-Pada Asana
pose_description: Hastpadasana is one of the twelve basic asanas. You must master this pose and its variations before trying the advanced Asanas.
pose_steps:
1) Stand erect and keep both the legs touching each other.
2) Take a deep breath and keep both the hands up.
3) Now go on exhaling. 
4) Bend in the front.
5) Place both the hands on the ground on both the sides of the legs. 
6) Touch the head on the knees. 
7) Do not bend the knees. 
8) Hold the breath outside. 
9) Stand steadily in this bent position.
pose_release: 1) Maintain position and suspension of breath 6 seconds.Inhale and then return to the starting position.
pose_benefits:
1) Disorders of the belly and digestive system are corrected. 
2) The chest and hands become stronger and you become well balanced, beautiful and good looking.
3) Diseases of the feet and fingers are also corrected.
pose_precautions: 1) Not for the people who have spinal problems, vertigo, hernia, cardiac problem, hypertension, ulcers, myopia.

other_names: Full Plough Posture, Full Plow Pose, Purn Hal Asan, Purna Hala Asana
pose_description: Halasana is repose, to assure maximum benefit. It consists in lying an instant on the back, then lifting the legs (firm) slowly over the trunk, helping to incline them with the pressure of the hands against the floor, to both sides of the head, the body forming a perfect arch.
pose_steps:
1) From the shoulder stand pose, bring your feet at an angle above your head.
2) Bring your hands behind your back to support and control the descent.
3) If possible bring gently the toes to the floor keeping your knees straight. 
4) Once the feet touch the floor bring your arms flat on the floor with palms down touching the floor.
5) For more advanced students, interlock the fingers keeping your hands in contact with the floor.
6) Try breathing as comfortably and rhythmically as possible.
7) If you do not have the necessary flexibility to do the full posture, it is okay to keep your feet up in the air and to let your knees be bent as required by your back muscles. 
8) Hold the asana from a few seconds to one minute.
pose_release:
1) To come out of the posture, lift your feet up to a 45 degree angle, bring your palms flat on the floor and slowly bring your back, hips, legs and feet onto the floor paying attention to keep the head and shoulders on the floor.
2) Relax on your back.
pose_benefits:
1) Brings fresh blood to the throat and thyroid gland.
2) Locking of the chin massages the thyroid gland.
3) Extends the cervical section of the spine giving it a powerful stretch. Same to the rest of the spine as well as hamstrings and calves.
4) During the inhalation intense pressure is applied to the abdomen giving a good stimulation to the digestive system.
5) Opens up the shoulder joints.
pose_precautions:
1) You should not do halasana if you have any neck problems. 
2) If you suffer from "rounded shoulders" a.k.a. kyphosis, do not stretch too far and do not hold the posture too long. 
3) Consult your doctor or chiropractor before practicing.

other_names: Thunderbolt Posture, Adamantine Pose, Vajra Asana, Vajr Asan
pose_description: Like Padmasana, this is also the Asana for meditation. One can sit comfortably for a prolonged period in this Asana. This is one asana which can be done immediately after consuming food. Sit in Vajrasana and do right nostril breathing.
pose_steps:
1) Sit with legs extended together, hands by the side of the body, palm resting on the ground, fingers of the hands together pointing forward.
2) Fold the right leg at the knee and place the foot under the right buttock. 
3) Sole will remain inside.
4) Similarly folding the left foot, place it under the left buttock.
5) Hands resting on the respective thighs.
6) Sit erect, gaze in front and then close the eyes.
pose_release:
1) While returning to the original position, bend little towards right side take out your left leg and extend it.
2) Similarly extend your right leg and return to the original position.
pose_benefits:
1) Relaxes your kneecaps, knees, ankles and feet, improves digestion and reduces gas.
3) Relieves sciatica pain. 'Vajrasana', if done for 10 minutes after a full meal relieves heaviness in stomach due to overeating.
pose_precautions:
1) While sitting on the bent feet, the heels should remain out and toes inside. Soles upward.
2) Do not sit on the heels.

other_names: Psychic union Pose, Psychio-union posture, Yog-Mudra Asan, Yogmudra Asana
pose_description: The word “Yogamudra” is derived from the two words – yoga (awareness) and mudra (seal). Yogamudra thus is the “seal of awareness”. It ensures that you attain the highest stage of awareness.
pose_steps:
1) Sit in Lotus Posture. 
2) Bring your hands behind your back.
3) Inhale deeply. 
4) Exhaling slowly, bend forward.
5) Exhale deeply. 
6) Come back to the sitting position inhaling slowly.
7) Again Sit in Lotus Posture by changing the leg crossed the other way. 
8) This time, hold the other wrist with the opposite hand.
pose_benefits:
1) Stretches the posterior muscles of the trunk and the neck. 
2) Improves muscle tone and venous circulation of the spinal column. 
3) Favourable effects on the viscera due to deep intra-abdominal compression. 
4) Lateral stretch stimulates vital areas of the colon. 
5) Acceleration of the venous flow from the sex organs has a favourable effect. 
6) The compression of the diaphragm and the abdominal walls provide massage to the abdominal contents useful in gastric conditions. 
7) Ascending and descending colon gets good pressure thereby alleviating constipation. 
8) Helps prevent sagging of uterus and postnatal laxities. 
9) Lumbar pain is alleviated. 
10) Overall, improves the health of the abdomen and pelvic organs due to good blood circulation and drainage.
pose_precautions:
1) Spinal injury and abnormalities, severe back problem and cervical and lumbar spondylosis. 
2) Hypertension, serious cardiac conditions, high BP, hernia and high myopia. 
3) Acute and resolving disc prolapsed (slip disc), acute pain of neck and back, the stiffness of back and joints, bulging tummy.

other_names: Corpse Posture, Most-relaxed Pose, supine posture, Savasana, Shav Asan, Sava Asana, Shava Mudra, Mritasana, Mrita, Mrit, Dead pose
pose_description: We can truly get in touch with the deepest of Anahata Chakra through Shavasana. In this asana, as we release the whole of the body into the ground and allow the full effect of gravity to flow through us then we restrain and retain Vayu Tattva.
pose_steps:
1) Lie flat on your back,Legs should be separated.
2 ) Keep your arms at your side and your palms facing up. Just relax.
3) Close your eyes and breathe deeply and slowly through the nostrils.
4) Start concentrating from your head to your feet. 
5) Don’t move ahead without relaxing particular part of the body.
6) On each inhaling and exhaling (breathing) think that your body is totally relaxed. 
7) Let your tension, stress, depression and worry run away on each exhaling. 
8) You can practice this asana for about 3–5 minutes.
pose_benefits:
1)  Savasana improves blood circulation. 
2) It helps in reducing stress.
3) Savasana boosts energy.
4) Relaxes your muscles.
5) Savasana helps reduce headaches.
6) Beneficial for those suffering from diabetes & indigestion
pose_precautions:
1) Constantly create shavasana earlier than practicing other yogasana and following ending yogasana.
2) That judgment hard to practice in the morning otherwise evening can do whereas resting at night.
3) Focus is significant.
4) Whereas practicing shavasana, if you experience drowsy otherwise sleepy you can respire a bit faster and deeper. 
5) Benefits of shavasana not only limit you to relaxing your body and mind, but it also has a huge part to play in your sleep. 
6) If you experience insomnia as such, you can easily try this yoga before hitting the bed. 
7) However, one should never fall asleep whilst doing the yoga which would hamper the gentle balance between relaxation and controlling your breathing.

other_names: Seated Mountain Pose, Seated Hill Posture, Parvata Asana, Parvat Asan
pose_description: In this the body is stretched to look like a mountain peak and so it is called the Parvatasana (parvat means mountain in Sanskrit).
pose_steps:
1) First, sit on the floor in Dandasana Position (staff pose) with legs stretched in front of you and hands kept freely beside the body.
2) Now, sit in the action of Padmasan means that your right leg is on the left thigh and the left leg is on the right thigh. (cross-legged pose)
3) After this, inhaling slow and deep about 3 seconds and join the palms in namaskar mudra and stretch the hands upward over the head.
4) Now pull the body and hands well upwards with keeping your hips on the floor and feel the deep stretch in the body. 
5) Maintain the final pose for 30-40 seconds.
6) With the breathing normally and then release the pose and slowly return to the starting pose.
pose_benefits:
1) The health benefits of Parvatasana is improving body balance and posture.
2) The practice of Seated Mountain Pose works to the spine and straightens the muscles of the back and enhances the functioning of the internal organs. 
3) When you practice this regularly, then your body becomes strong and the looseness of the body also removes.
4) Parvatsana also removes tension in the shoulders and back.
5) This asana benefits both men and women alike, and full benefit can be obtained in the disease of premature ejaculation.
6) Parvatsana is very effective for the strength of the shoulders. And the power of the legs also increases.
7) Apart from that, this pose also activates the heart chakra which helps one to feel sensations of deep love and peace.
8) There is no better way to get rid of lungs or respiratory diseases than emigration.
9) To overcome uterine diseases and to eliminate the flexibility of the skin after pregnancy, one should do it.
10) A person who has the disease of early degeneration must do this asana. 
11) According to experts, this disease is curing by this asana.
pose_precautions:
1) Parvatsana may be good for your health, but here are some precautions that Anantasana will bring about.
2) Don’t practice this pose’s full extension in case you have carpal tunnel syndrome since it places much stress on hands and the wrists. Rather, modify this posture by resting the forearms on the ground instead of holding your body up with the hands.
3) When you do this asana, you should not be bowed down at your hands, keep your waist and hands fingers straight.
4) During practice, if you find any pain or discomfort, please exit the pose and ask for the expert’s guidance and doctor’s advice.

other_names: Triangle Posture, Trikon Asan, Trikona Asan, Side Bend Pose
pose_description: Trikonasana, the Triangle Pose, concludes the yoga postures in our Basic Session. It augments the movement of the Half Spinal Twist Yoga Pose and gives an excellent lateral stretch to the spine, toning the spinal nerves and helping the proper functioning of the digestive system.
pose_steps:
1) Move the legs 3-4 feet distance apart. Raise both the arms straight out to the sides, in line with the shoulders and parallel to the floor with the palms facing downwards.
2) Move the right foot to the outside direction. Turn the left foot slightly to the inward direction. The knees must remain straight throughout the practice.
3) Slowly begin to bend the trunk towards the right side. Make sure the body doesn’t go in the forward direction.
4) Once the trunk is completely bent the hand must be close to the right ankle with the fingers slightly touching the floor. 
5) Ideally the right palm rest on the floor. Avoid forcing this position as with regular practice it comes easily on the floor.
6) Stretch the left arm vertically. Move the head in the upward direction and look straight.               
7) Hold the position for a minute or half or even lesser in the beginning. Gradually increasing the time as you begin to feel more comfortable.
8) To return, lift the arms first and then slowly move the trunk back in the upright position. Relax the body.Practice this asana 1-3 times on both the sides.
pose_release:
1) Stand upright keeping the spine erect, head straight, feet together with big toes and heels slightly touching each other. Hands to the side of the body. 
2) The weight of the body should neither be on the heels nor on the toes but distributed evenly on both of them. 
3) Relax and take deep breaths.
pose_benefits:
1) Stretches and strengthens the thighs,  knees, and ankles. 
2) Stretches the hips, groins, hamstrings, and calves; shoulders,  chest and spine. 
3) Stimulates the abdominal organs. 
4) Helps relieve stress. 
5) Improves digestion. 
6) Helps relieve the symptoms of menopause.
pose_precautions:
1) Don’t overstretch the body while practicing this asana as it may cause unnecessary pain or injury.
2) If the neck begins to hurt in the upward direction, slightly lower it.
3) Avoid practicing this asana in case of severe pain in the neck, back or shoulders.
4) People suffering from any of these conditions should avoid practicing this asana: any kind of injury in the knee, arthritis, vertigo, spinal disorders, high blood pressure, breathing trouble, migraine, heart problem or cervical spondylitis.

other_names: Peacock Posture, Pea-Cock Pose, Mayura Asana, Mayur Asan
pose_description: It is a classic yoga posture that is highly recommended if you want to improve the radiance of your skin, the tone of your muscles and the workings of your inner organs. In this asana one has to hold his whole body like a stick on both his elbows.
pose_steps:
1) Start the pose by gently sitting on the heels. Keep your knees wide apart.
2) Keep your hands on the floor and point the fingers towards your body. Bend your elbows gently and slowly press them towards the abdomen.
3) During the pose, you should always keep the belly firm. This is something that you can do by dropping your head on the floor and enhancing the strength of your stomach.
4) Stretch out your legs while making sure that your knees remain straight. You should also keep the upper part of the feet facing the floor.
5) Keep your shoulder blades firm and push them into the back. Raise your head and tighten your buttocks. 
6) Keep your gaze forward.
7) Slowly shift the weight of your body forward while lifting the legs right off the floor. Make sure you’re your body is lifted with its weight balanced on the hands. 
8) You should keep your body parallel to the surface of the floor.
9) Stay on this pose for about ten seconds at the initial stages. With more practice, you can to hold on to the pose for up to 1 minute.
pose_benefits:
1) According to the Gheranda Samhita, Mayurasana can help in removing toxins from the body. It can detoxify the body and remove fevers and tumors.
2) Mayurasana energizes the stomach, pancreas, spleen, liver, kidneys, and intestines.
3)The asana tones digestive organs and also increases blood circulation within the abdominal area, thus enhancing its strength.
4) The yoga asana tones and strengthens the reproductive system, thereby reducing all menopause and menstrual dysfunctions. Mayurasana can also enhance sexual activity.
5) It can also assist in fighting piles and diabetes.
6) It can help in improving posture.
7) The asana helps to calm the restless mind and greatly reduce anxiety and stress.
8) Practicing Mayurasana helps to boost the strength of the shoulders, wrist, elbows, and spine.
9) It improves focus and concentration and also the coordination between mind and body.
pose_precautions:
1) Do not practice Mayurasana if you already have a wrist, elbow or shoulder injury.
2) You should strictly avoid Mayurasana if you have high blood pressure; heart diseases; intestinal problems; a hernia; eye, nose and ear infections or brain tumor.
3) Pregnant and menstruating women should not practice Mayurasana.
4) If you are not feeling well while practicing Mayurasana, immediately come out of the pose.
5) Now that you have learned about the various steps associated with Mayurasana, go ahead and practice it to attain the maximum benefits.

other_names: Frog Pose, Froggy Posture, Manduka Asana, Manduk Asan
pose_description: The shape of this formation resembles a frog, so that’s why this asana is called Mandukasana. In sanskrit frog is called a manduk.
pose_steps:
1) Sit in Vajrasana.
2) Now, make fists where thumbs should be inside.
3) Put the fists at the naval region.
4) Inhale deeply.
5) With exhale bend forward and put maximum pressure on the naval area. 
6) While bending forward, your chest should touch your thigh and see ahead with open eyes just like as frog.
7) Maintain the pose as long as you can do.
8) Inhale-exhale slowing while maintaining the pose.
9) Come to Vajrasana with deep inhale.
10) Perform it 3 to 5 times.
pose_benefits:
1) massages the entire abdominal organs. Thus, good for smooth functioning of these organs.
2) It controls weight. Thus effective for those who are longing for weight loss and making the stomach flat.
3) It is beneficial in case of constipation and indigestion.
4) It is helpful to release unwanted gases from the stomach thus make you feel relaxed and calm.
5) It helps to control diabetes by stimulating the pancreas.
6) Dislocated naval can be corrected by performing this asana.
7) It should be practiced by those who have asthmatic condition.
8) It strengthens the back if practice technically right. \m9) It is good for chest and shoulders.
10) Regular practicing the asana is helpful to minimize the impact of menstrual cramps.
11) It can be practiced to relieve stress, anxiety and depression.
12) In traditional texts, it has also been said that the asana helps to awakening of Kundalini.
pose_precautions:
1) It shouldn’t be performed by those who has backache
2) It shouldn’t be practiced who has ulcer.
3) Knee pain patients should avoid it.
4) Don’t put maximum stretch on your stomach; try to maintain the pose for longer period of time.
5) Avoid if having ankle injuries.
6) High blood pressure
7) Insomnia
8) Migraine

pose_description: This exercise is also one of the basic breathing exercises. The breathing technique Sitali refers to the sound caused when air is drawn in through the protruding tongue folded into a tube.
pose_steps:
1) Sit in front of yoga mat at any meditative posture like Padmasana, Sukhasana or in Vajrasana with head, neck, and spine erect in one line. 
2) Also, to make practice more effective, you can make Gyan Mudra with your hands.
3) Breathe in deeply 2-3 times with your mouth open, and exhale from the nose to prepare for the sitali breathing.
4) Bring out your tongue while curling it on sides towards the center to form a tube-like shape.
5) Now inhale through the tube-form tongue and towards the end of inhalation, lower your chin to the chest in ‘Jalandhara Bandha’. 
6)  At this point, hold your breath for 6-8 secs.
7) Before exhaling, lift up your chin, withdraw your tongue & close your mouth. 
8) Now exhale completely through your nostrils. 
9) This completes one round sitali breathing.
pose_benefits:
1) A research 1 done on the effect of Sitali along with sitkari pranayama on Brain waves has shown, it increases the alpha, delta, and theta waves power and decreases beta wave power.
2) Where alpha waves bend mostly seen in the calm and quiet brains, beta waves observed in mind full of fear and anxiety.
3) It relieves you from stress & anxiety through its soothing & relaxing effect.
4) It also helps reduce fever by bringing down body temperature.
5) Do this when you feel hot during summers to cool down.
6) It helps calm down hunger and thirst in an emergency situation.
7) Its repetitions 3-4 times a day can help bring down overall body temperature by 3 to 4% during summers.
8) It also helps in lowering blood pressure.
9) Sitali Pranayama is very useful for people suffering from Insomnia. Its regular practice will help cure them of insomnia.
10)It is very helpful for people suffering from a sleep disorder. It helps them relax and sleep well for up to 8 hours at night.
pose_precautions:
1) For the effective results out of this breathing exercise, it’s preferred to practice it in empty stomach.
2) Make sure your back and neck are not bent or curved as it restricts the Prana flow within the subtle body.
3) Unlike other pranayamas, avoid doing Sitali. 
4) Pranayama during winters and extreme cold weather as it could induce respiratory problems in your lungs
5) Those having heart ailments should consult a doctor or an experienced Yoga trainer before trying to do Sitali Pranayama.

other_names: Waist Rotating Pose, Waist rotation posture, Katti-Chakra Asana, Kati-Chakrasana, Kati Chakr Asan, Kati-Chakrasana, KatiChakrasana
pose_description: This also a simple yet effective and safe posture which almost any one can practice to mainly exercise the trunk. Its easily controllable circular movement is a good remedy for back pains.
pose_steps:
1) Begin with Tadasana, stand straight keeping your feet comfortably apart.
2)  Inhaling, stretch both arms front of the chest with your palms are facing each other. Distance between the arms should remain constant.
3)  Rotate your waist to the right swinging your arms as far as possible while exhaling. Check your breath and maintain this pose as long as you can. Bring your arms before the chest while inhaling.
4)  Now rotate your waist to the left swinging your arms as far as possible while exhaling. Check your breath and maintain this pose as long as you can. Bring your arms before the chest while inhaling.
5)  This is one cycle. Perform minimum 5 cycles at a time.
pose_benefits:
1) Healthy maintenance of the spinal column.
2) Regular practice of Katichakrasana burns waist and abdominal fat. Enjoy slim, supple and flexible waist. If you are worried about belly fat, practice Katichakrasana everyday and lose fat (weight) in the abdominal region.
3) Flexible spine, neck and back muscle - contraction and expansion in the neck, back, waist and abdominal region massages and tones the muscles in these regions massaging the entire vertebral column.
4) Improves bowel movement, helps cure indigestion and constipation.
5) Strengthened shoulders, neck, arms, back and thighs.
6) While rotating the waist and moving the arms in the same direction, chest expands and oxygen fills the lungs. This yoga pose helps combat asthma, cough, tuberculosis, etc.
7) Eases muscular stiffness and rigidity – people suffering from Parkinson’s and Alzheimer diseases and those with frozen shoulder will be highly benefited.
8) Regulates the production of pancreatic juice, controls diabetes by improving the efficiency of pancreas.
9) Improves kidney efficiency, nervous system, helps fight depression by releasing pranic energy and elevating mood, stimulates Manipura Chakra, cures uterus problems, strengthens lumbar region, strengthens arms and leg muscles, and more.
pose_precautions:
1) Don’t practice Katichakrasana if you are pregnant.
2) People with hernia, slip disk, spinal injuries, cervical spondylitis and those who have gone through abdominal surgery recently should avoid this asana.
3) If you have high blood pressure, be cautious while practicing Katichakrasana. This practice may cause giddiness and faintness in you.

other_names: Mountain Pose, Hill Posture, Tada Asana, Tad Asan,
pose_description: Tadasana can be practiced as a starting position for standing poses, in between standing poses, or by itself to improve posture. Tadasana is a position used at the beginning and in the middle and in the end, in which you pay attention to your position, your concentration and your breathing.
pose_steps:
1) Stand straight and keep some distance between feet.
2) Hands should be hanging alongside your body.
3) Now while deep inhaling raise your both the arms upwards and interlock your fingers.
4) Raise your heels and stand on your toes. Feel the stretch in your body from feet to fingers of arms.
5) Hold this position and your breath for 10 seconds.
6) Now while exhaling release your pose to come to the starting position.
7) Repeat this cycle for 10 times.
pose_benefits:
\1) One of the best yoga poses to increase height.
2) Stimulates nervous system.
3) Improves body posture and balance.
4) Regulate the menstrual cycle in women.
5) Tone your buttocks and abdomen.
6) Strengthens your ankles, knees, thighs, arms, and legs.
7) Improves the function of the respiratory and digestive system.
pose_precautions:
1) Those who are suffering from insomnia, low blood pressure or a headache should not practice tadasana yoga pose.
2) Should not practice during pregnancy.

other_names: Twisting Posture, Twist Pose, Vakra Asana, Vakr Asan
pose_description: In this asana, the upper part of the body is completely turned and twisted. The spine, the muscles of the hands, the legs and the back are stretched.
pose_steps:
1) Sit on the mat with your legs stretched out in front of you.
2) Keep your hands parallel to hips or thighs with palms resting on the floor.
3)  Bend your left knee at 90 degrees with knee pointing towards the sky, placing the left foot near your right knee. 
4) Bring your right hand forward, place it on the outer side of your folded left knee while twisting your waist. 
5) Note that your right elbow should be touching the left knee. Now hold your left ankle with your right hand.
6)  Turn your head to your left and place your left hand flat on the floor, just behind the hip. Hold this position for a count of 30 and breathe normally.
7) Now release your hand holding the right ankle and your left twist, turn your head and stretch your legs.
8) Keep your palms on the mat in a relaxed position and rest for 10 seconds.
9) Repeat the same for the other side.
pose_benefits:
1) It stimulates the pancreas and is therefore beneficial for people with diabetes
2) It helps reduce belly fat
3) It relieves the stiffness of the spine
4) It helps with proper secretion of stomach acid, which helps correct digestion problems
5) It helps in relieving symptoms of constipation and liver weakness
6) It increases elasticity of the spine and makes it supple
7) It tones spinal nerves
8) It strengthens back muscles and reduces back ache
pose_precautions:
1) Our yoga expert has adapted these poses to suit diabetics. Sometimes, diabetics have restricted range of movement, due to obesity or overall stiffness. 
2) The poses demonstrated have been adapted to make room for these restrictions. 
3) So go ahead and start gently. If you have never done yoga before or have some other complication due to which your doctor has restricted your movement, do check with him/her before you begin.

other_names: Full Boat Posture, Purna Nauka, Noka, Asan Nav Asana, Boat Pose
pose_description: Although this asana is done on the floor, but actually it is a challenging balancing pose (the balance is on your buttocks). The complete posture looks like a boat, and since you are balancing like a boat balances in the water.
pose_steps:
1) Sit with your knees bent, feet on the floor. Place your hands behind your knees, lift the chest, engaging the back muscles as you inhale
2) Engage your inner thighs and draw your lower belly in and up
3) Tip back on the back of your sitting bones and lift your feet up to about knee height, toes spread out
4) Bring your arms parallel to the floor
5)To go further, straighten your legs
6) Stay for 2-5 breaths, work up to 10 breaths
7) To come out of the pose, on an exhalation bring your feet down, and sit with a straight spine, holding on to your legs for a couple of breaths
pose_benefits:
1) Strengthens core, hip flexors and spine
2) Improves digestion
pose_precautions:
In the following conditions, navasana should be avoided or one should consult a expert before practicing it.
1) Hernia
2) Spinal injuries
3) Blood pressure
4) Asthma
5) Heart patients
6) Pregnancy
7) Hip joint pain
8) Migraine
9) Diarrhea
10) Heart problems
11) Insomnia
12) Neck injury

pose_description: This bandh involves movement of the muscles of the stomach and especially the muscles of the diaphragm. The movement is important and characteristic. Hathayoga assigns a special importance to Uddiyan Bandh. The study of Pranayam is not complete without studying this bandh.
pose_steps:
1) Standing Position
2) Firstly, stand and keep your spine straight.
3) Then, bend your knees slightly, keep around a feet distance between them.
4) Now, slightly lean forward and put your hands on thighs, just above the knees.
5) Take a couple of breaths and relax.
 Sitting Position
6) Sit in a Yoga Asana such as Padmasana or Siddhasna. Get comfortable with the asana.
7) Place your hands on the lower thighs, just above the kneecap.
8) Take a couple of deep breaths to let a proper flow of prana throughout the body.
9) Now you have to focus on your abdomen and perform the following steps.
 Steps to Perform Uddiyana Bandha
10) Exhale the breath completely, and hold it.
11) Now, draw the navel part in and try to touch your spine, then lift it towards your ribcage or heart’s center, holding the breath.
12) Hold it for a few seconds, according to your comfort the drop it gently.
13) Do this all process simultaneously.
pose_benefits:
1) Uddiyana Bandha mainly uses the muscles of the abdominal region. It is like an exercise for the abdomen muscles. As a result, it strengthens the abdominal muscles and diaphragm.
2) This practice massages the abdominal muscles heart and the lungs that result in a better function of these muscles. It increases digestive fire in the body. As a result, it improves digestion and purifies the toxins from our body.
pose_precautions:
1) If you are suffering from high blood pressure problems, you should not go for Uddiyana Bandha. 
2) Practicing it can increase your blood pressure rapidly.
3) The patients of ulcer and hernia are not suggested to perform Uddiyana Bandha.
4) During pregnancy, a woman should not practice this Bandha. It can have an adverse effect on the health of unborn and mother, both.
5) In mensuration cycles, one should not practice Uddiyana Bandha.
6) You should perform it empty stomach, if you’ll perform this just after a meal, this can cause stomach pain and indigestion.
7) Don’t go much hard on your body. Ones you have reached your limit, you can release yourself. Going beyond the limit can be damaging to your health.

other_names: Hero Posture/ Pose 2, Veera or Vira Asana, Veer or Vir Asan, Veerasana
pose_description: Vira means brave. The way a brave man takes position while attacking his enemy, the similar position is formed in this asana, hence it is called as Virasana.
pose_steps:
1) Start the pose by kneeling down. Spread your feet apart to sit between them.
2) Do not sit ON your feet. Keep your feet outside your hips. Your toes should be pointing backward, and your feet’s tops should be pressing onto the floor.
3) Do not keep your knees wider than your hips. Now lie down on your back slowly by first using your hands, then your elbows.(If you feel pain or discomfort in your back or knees, then stop practicing the pose.)
4) Hold this pose for 20-30 seconds. Then raise your body slowly, using your hands to come back to the starting position.
pose_benefits:
1) Improves your digestion greatly
2) Relaxes the muscles of your legs and knees
3) Relieves tired legs
4) It also cures several medical conditions like Insomnia, Infertility, Headache, Flat Feet, Acidity, Diarrhea, Arthritis, High Blood Pressure, and Gastritis
5) Relieves menstrual pain
6) Stretches your abdomen, thighs, and your ankles
7) Supta Virasana strengthens your arches
8) Relieves Sciatica
pose_precautions:
1) Do not eat anything before doing any yoga pose. 
2) Always practice yoga on empty stomach only.
3) Use props like blocks, straps and bolsters if you’re a beginner or have difficulty in doing it.
4) Don’t practice Supta Virasana if you have knee or ankle injury.
5) Consult a doctor if you have a history of severe back, ankle or knee problems.
6) Do not keep your knees wider than your hips.

other_names: Camel Pose, Ustrasana, Unt or Unth Posture, Ustra or Ushtra Asana
pose_description: The word “ushtra” refers to “Camel”. In this asana, the body resembles the neck of a camel, that's why it is called 'Ushtrasana'.
pose_steps:
1) Starting Position: Vajrasana
2) Stand on the knees. Keep the thighs fully straight.
3) Keep the knees and feet together. But if one feels more comfortable with maintaining a little distance between them, they may do so.
4) Lean in the backward direction. Slowly move more backward. Reach the right heel with the right hand, and the left heel with the left hand. Avoid straining the body.
5) Push the hips in the forward direction. The thighs should be kept vertical.
6) Then bend the head and the spine as backward and as farther as possible without straining.
7) Relax the body and the muscles of the back.
8) Support the body weight equally on the legs and arms.
9) Keep the arms in such a way that they anchor the shoulders to maintain the back arch.
10) Stay in the same position for as long as you find it comfortable.
11) Then release the hands from the heels one by one and return to the starting position. Relax and take deep breaths.
12)  Practice 3 times, must be followed or proceeded by a forward bending asana such as Paschimottanasana (Seated Forward Bend).
pose_benefits:
1) Helpful in getting rid of all kinds of back pain.
2) Stimulates the functioning of the thyroid gland.
3) Makes the neck, back, chest and abdominal regions flexible.
4) Stretches pelvic region thus helpful in getting rid of menstrual discomforts.
5) Improves digestion and reduces excess fat deposited on the stomach, neck and back.
6) Activates the brain cells and makes it function better by improving the blood circulation.
7) Beneficial for curing the diseases related to the respiratory system such as Bronchitis and Asthma.
pose_precautions:
1) Breath normally throughout the practice. Avoid long and deep breaths as the chest is already stretched during this asana and taking long, deep breaths may create discomfort in breathing.
2) Beginners after practicing Ustrasana may feel dizzy for a while. It may also cause nausea as well but that’s very rare.
3) People suffering from high or low blood pressure should avoid practicing this asana.
4) People suffering from insomnia should avoid this asana.
5) Ustrasana should be avoided by people having any back injury or pain in the neck.
6) Ustrasana is not recommended for people suffering from a migraine.

other_names: Side Bending Stretch Pose, Swaying Palm Tree Pose, Tiriyaka-Tada-Asana, Triyak-Tad-Asan
pose_description: Tiriyaka-Tadasana is a swaying tree stretch. This pose can be seen in trees when wind is blowing.
pose_steps:
1) Starting Position: Tadasana (Mountain Pose)Variation 1
2) Tiryaka Tadasana (Swaying Palm Tree Pose) steps, precautions benefitsDistance your legs shoulder-width
3) Interlock the fingers of both of your hands with the palms facing outward direction.
4) While inhaling, slowly raise the arms bringing them over the head. Now the palms must be facing upwards.
5) Stretch the arms in the upward direction, they should be slightly touching the ears.
6) While exhaling, slowly begin to lower the torso to the right side of the body as far as can comfortable.
7) Keep the arms straight. You will feel a good stretch on the left side of your waist.
8) Retain this position for a few seconds.
9) To return, exhale and slowly move the torso to the upright position. Lower the hands and release the interlock.
10) Relax the body taking long and deep breaths. Practice from opposite side.
11) Practice 3 times with each side alternately.
 Variation 2
12) Balance the body on toes before bending sideways in this variation.Tiryaka Tadasana (Swaying Palm Tree Pose) steps, benefits Image Source
13) Precautions for Tiryaka Tadasana (Swaying Palm Tree Pose)
14) It is recommended to begin a yoga practice in the presence of a competent yoga teacher/instructor.
15) Bending must go only sideways. Ensure the torso doesn’t move in forward or backward Avoid applying force while bending as that may strain the muscles.
16) If you suffer from any of this condition, avoid practicing Swaying Palm Tree Pose: cardiac problem, hernia, back pain, slipped disc, vertigo, spinal injuries, knee problems, frequent headaches or high blood pressure.
pose_benefits:
1) Prevents osteoporosis in aged people.
2) Helpful in getting rid of constipation and gastritis.
3) A perfect asana for the beginners to develop a strong core.
4) Stretches the muscles of the back and joints of the spinal column.
5) Balances left and right postural muscles thus improving the posture.
6) Loosens, tones up and massages the sides of the waists, therefore, removing excess fat.
7) A useful posture for pregnant women as practicing it relieves a backache and muscular pain.
8) Stimulates the functioning of liver, kidney, spleen and digestive system. 
9) Removes constipation.
10) Beneficial for people suffering from bronchitis, bronchiectasis, asthma and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).
pose_precautions:
1) People suffering from hernia should not practice.
2) If you are suffering from back pain, then don’t practice it.
3) This practice is prohibited for those who are suffering from hypertension and any cardiac problem
4) If you have cervical pain, it advised to leave the practice.
5) People suffering from severe headache should not practice this asana.

other_names: Triangle Posture, Trikon Asan, Trikona Asan, Side Bend Pose
pose_description: Trikonasana, the Triangle Pose, concludes the yoga postures in our Basic Session. It augments the movement of the Half Spinal Twist Yoga Pose and gives an excellent lateral stretch to the spine, toning the spinal nerves and helping the proper functioning of the digestive system.
pose_steps:
1) Stand erect. Now, keep distance between your legs about 3 to 4 feet
2) Extend your arms at the shoulder level.
3) Inhale and raises your right arm by the side of your head.
4) Now, bend your right arms with exhaling towards the left side by keeping your bodyweight equally on both the feet. 
5) You should ensure that the right arm becomes parallel to the ground.
6) Maintain the position as per your comfort with normal breathing and come to the original position by inhaling.
7) Do the same procedure with the left arm.
8) Perform three to five rounds of trikonasana.
pose_benefits:
1) This asana is good to burn fat. Therefore, it is recommended to a person who is facing the conditions of weight and obesity.
2) It is good for your backache
3) This Yoga pose is recommended for growing children to increase their height.
4) Triangle pose helps to strengthen your legs, knees, and ankles.
5) Good for your digestion
6) It may be used for stress management.
7) Triangle pose helps to expand your chest and shoulders.
8) It ensures the mobility of hip joints and neck and gives proper stretch to your spine.
9) It strengthens the muscles in the thighs, hips, and back. 
10) It provides stamina, balance, energy and develops focus.
pose_precautions:
1) This asana shouldn’t be performed who has severe back pain.
2) Avoid this yoga who is suffering from migraines.
3) A person is detected with diarrhea, high blood pressure, neck & back injuries, shouldn’t perform this asana.
4) Those who are experiencing dizziness shouldn’t look down at the floor during the final stage.
5) Cervical spondylosis should do it with proper precautions.
6) Don’t take the support of your knee while performing this asana as it exerts excess pressure on your knee that may lead to knee problems.
7) Having neck problems, don’t look up while performing this asana. It is better to gaze straight or look down at the floor.

other_names: Downward-Facing Dog Posture, headstand pose, downward facing tree, Adho Mukh Sav Asan, Savasana, Shavasana
pose_description: This asana is one of the most widely recognized yoga poses, Downward-Facing Dog is an all-over, rejuvenating stretch. Downward-facing dog is an ancient posture depicted in Egyptian Art that is thousands of years old. It teaches us that how everything is connected; how our heels are linked to our shoulders, how fingers influence heart, how our elbow placement effects the spine.
pose_steps:
1) Stand on four limbs, such that your body forms a table-like structure.
2) Exhale and gently lift your hips and straighten your elbows and knees. You need to ensure your body forms an inverted ‘V’.
3) Your hands should be in line with your shoulders, and your feet in line with your hips. Make sure that your toes point outwards.
4) Now, press your hands into the ground and lengthen your neck. Your ears should touch your inner arms, and you should turn your gaze to your navel.
5) Hold for a few seconds, and then, bend your knees and return to the table position.
pose_benefits:
1) Strengthens The Abdominal MusclesThe inversion of the downward facing dog pose is the boat pose. We all know that the Navasana benefits the abdominal muscles that also help support the spine. This exercise has similar effects on the abdominal muscles. It helps to stretch and strengthen these muscles.
2) Improves CirculationIt might not have come to your notice, but the downward facing dog is actually an inversion. The hips are lifted, and the head is dropped below the heart. There is a reversal in the pull of gravity, so fresh blood flows, thus promoting circulation.
3) Improves DigestionThis asana is not a full fold, but it still allows the abdominal muscles to compress the organs of the digestive system, including the liver, kidneys, and the spleen.
4) Tones The Hands And FeetThe body weight is on your hands and feet when you do the Adho Mukha Svanasana. Therefore, it tones the limbs and prepares them for better balance.
5) Decreases AnxietyThis pose also helps you relax and calms your mind, thus reducing anxiety. As the neck and cervical spine are stretched, stress is released.
pose_precautions:
Avoid practicing this asana if you suffer from
1) Carpal tunnel syndrome
2) High blood pressure
3) A detached retina
4) A dislocated shoulder
5) Weak eye capillaries
6) Diarrhoea.
7) Pregnant women should practice this asana with caution. 
8) It is best to consult your doctor before you indulge in the practice.

other_names: Child Posture, Baby Pose, Foetus Pose, Bal Asan, Bala Asana, Garbhasana, Gharbha Asana, Gharabh Asan
pose_description: Balasana is a resting pose that can precede or follow any asana. It looks like a foetus that’s why it is also called Foetus pose or Garbhasana.
pose_steps:
1)  Sit on your heels on a yoga mat or on the floor.
2) Either keep your knees together or apart.
3) Slowly, bend forward by lowering your forehead to touch the floor, exhaling as you do so.
4) Keep your arms alongside your body. Make sure that your palms are facing up.
5) Alternatively, you can reach out your arms towards the front of the yoga mat, palms placed facing down on the mat.
6) Now that you are in this pose, gently press your chest on the thighs (or between the thighs if the latter are apart). balasana
7) Hold for 45 seconds to 1 minute. Regulate your breath.
8) As you inhale, imagine your breath is being driven through your navel, and pull your navel towards your spine.Listen to the latest songs, only on JioSaavn.com
9) As you exhale, soften your body and the arms. Repeat for 4-12 breaths.
10) Place your palms under the shoulders and gradually raise your upper body to return to the sitting position on the heels while inhaling. Do this very slowly as if uncurling the spine.COMMENTS11) Relax.
pose_benefits:
1) Helps relieve fatigue. As this is a resting pose, it helps relax the body. The regulated breathing helps restore you to a state of calmness.
2) For the reasons mentioned above, this is also a great pose to ease anxiety and stress. Being curled up, makes one aware of the breathing pattern. Focussing on the breathing helps relax the mind.
3) The pose helps lengthen and stretch out the spine.
4) It also gently stretches the ankles, hips and shoulders.
5) Stimulates digestion and elimination.
6) By stretching the spine, it also helps ease neck and back pain.
pose_precautions:
This pose should not be performed if you fall in any of the below categories:
1) Pregnant women
2) Suffering from diarrhoea
3) Knee injury

pose_description: Bhastrika is primarily consists of forced rapid deep breathing which serves as a basis for many varieties of exercises, all of which may be described by the same name. Although air is forced both in and out, the emphasis is placed upon the expulsion or explosion of air.
pose_steps:
1) Sit in Padmasana (Lotus Pose).
2)Take a deep breath and fill your lungs with air.
3) Release the breath after counting till five.
4) Listen to the latest songs, only on JioSaavn.com
5) Now begin practicing the technique by inhaling and exhaling with force and mimicking the panting activity.
6) To begin with, practice at least 21 times (one round of inhalation and exhalation will count as one time).You can take breaks and continue doing it for three minutes. 
7)  Gradually increase the count and the duration as the stamina increases.
pose_benefits:
1) It is good for brain oxygenation.
2) It benefits the nervous and the motor system.
3) It is great for energizing the body and the mind
4) Good for people with depression and anxiety
5) It helps in treating fibrosis
6) Great for lungs and people who suffer from repetitive cough, flu, respiratory issues, allergies or breathlessness
7) Helps strengthen immunity
8) Checks sleep apnea as well.
pose_precautions:
1) People with hypertension and heart issues must not attempt practicing Bhastrika. 
2) Pregnant women should also steer clear of it. 
3) Don't practice Bhastrika while you're undergoing a migraine attack

other_names: Ujjayi, Ujjayee, Victorious Breath, Ocean Breath, Loud Breathing
