pose_description: In Ujjai breathing, the glottis is partially closed. The glottis is that part in the throat area that closes when you swallow, but which is open when you breath. When you partially close the glottis while breathing, you can hear a sound resonate from within, as well as feel a flow of air on the palate. A slightly different sound is heard on inhalation and exhalation.
pose_steps:
1) Close the mouth and constrict the throat (the glottis — a part of larynx).
2) Make a short exhalation and then start inhaling—slowly and rhythmically in one long and unbroken inspiration.
3) Allow the air to pass through the constricted throat, creating a “friction sound”.
4) Continue inhaling till a sense of fullness is felt in the chest.
5) Retain the inhaled air for a period of 6 seconds (preferably double the period of inspiration).
6) Ensure: While sitting spine, head and neck is maintained erect.
7) Facial muscles are relaxed and nose is not constricted. Inhalation is slow and rhythmic – long, unbroken and without jerks.
8) Now exhale as naturally as possible – gradually, avoiding jerky or hasty movements.
9) Take few normal breaths and relax.
pose_benefits:
1) Helps rectify fluid retention in the body (edema/ dropsy).
2) Clears phlegm & increases appetite.
3) Beneficial in chronic cold, cough, indigestion, liver problems, dysentery, fever and other diseases.
4) Ghatashudhhi or purification of seven dhatus (elements) Skin, flesh, blood, bones, marrow, fat and semen.
5) There is enrichment of the voice.
6) Stimulates and balances the thyroid.
pose_precautions:
1) Not recommended in serious cardiac and hypertension cases. 
2) Can practice without retention of breath.

pose_description: This pose gives you a sense of grounding. It improves your balance and strengthens your legs and back. It replicates the steady stance of a tree.
pose_steps:
1) Place your right foot high up on your left thigh. The sole of the foot should be flat and placed firmly. 
2)  Keep your left leg straight and find your balance. 
3) While inhaling, raise your arms over your head and bring your palms together. 
4) Ensure that your spine is straight and take a few deep breaths. 
5) Slowly exhale, bring your hands down and release your right leg. 
6) Back in the standing position repeat the same with the other leg.
pose_benefits:
1) It stretches the entire body from toes to fingers, thus invigorates you.
2) It gives tranquillity to your mind thus good for those who are facing the problem of depression and anxiety.
3) It increases your stamina, concentration and immunity.
4)It is good for your hips as it helps to open it.
5) It is beneficial for those who are experiencing sciatica. But one should practice it under the supervision of a yoga expert.
6) It enhances the flexibility of legs, back and chest muscles.
7) It makes your ankle stronger.
8) It should be performed as knees yoga.  The person who is having knee problems should perform it.
9) It strengthens thighs and calves.
10) It gives suitable stretching to the groins.
11) Person suffering from flat feet should practice it.
12) It makes you more focused and concentrated.
13) By practicing this asana, the ligaments and tendons of the feet gets strengthen.
14) It is also good for pelvic region.
15) It develops esteem and self-confidence.
16) It calms and relaxes the central nervous system.
17) It helps to cure rheumatic pain and also treats numbness.
pose_precautions:
It should not be practiced in case of
1) High blood pressure
2) Low blood pressure
3) Migraine
4) Insomnia
5) Acute knee problems
6) Hip injury

pose_description: An intensely powerful pose, this one strengthens the muscles of the legs and arms. It builds your willpower and has an energizing effect on the body and mind. Stand straight with your feet slightly apart.
pose_steps:
1) Stretch your arms but don't bend your elbow. Inhale and bend your knees, pushing your pelvis down like you are sitting on chair. 
2) Keep your hands parallel to the ground and back straight. 
3) Take deep breaths. 
4) Bend gradually but make sure your knees don't go beyond your toes
pose_release:
1) While inhalation straightens knees.
2) Exhale and release arms beside the body and come to a normal position.
pose_benefits:
1) Strengthens and stabilize the ankles, thighs, calves, spine, abdominal and lower back muscles.
2) Stimulates the abdominal organs, diaphragm, and heart.
3) Improve function of respiratory, digestive and circulatory systems
4) Opens and stretches the chest and shoulders.
5) Improves confidence, sense of balance and focus.
6)Therapeutic for flat feet.
pose_precautions:
Avoided during : 
1) Headache
2) Insomnia
3) High or Low blood pressure
4) Shoulder, Spine, thigh or hip problems

pose_description: It tightens the abdominal muscles and strengthens shoulders and upper back. It leaves the practitioner with a sense of stability.
pose_steps:
1) Lie back on the mat with your feet together and hands by your side. 
2) Take a deep breath and while exhaling gently lift your chest and feet off the ground. 
3) Stretch your hands in the direction of your feet. 
4)  Your eyes, fingers and toes should be in one line. 
5) Hold till you feel some tension in your navel area as your abdominal muscles begin to contract. 
6) As you exhale, come back to the ground and relax.
pose_benefits:
1) Naukasana strengthens the abdominal muscles.
2) It strengthens the muscles of the arms, thighs and shoulders.
3) It improves the health of all organs in the abdomen especially the liver, pancreas and kidneys.
4) It helps in regulating blood flow at sugar level.
5) It toughens muscles of neck, shoulder and the legs.
6) The stretching, compressing and relaxation of the abdominal region involved with Naukasana is a really good and effective way of burning belly fat if practiced on a regular basis.
7) The stimulation while performing the pose helps improve and regulate your digestion, including alleviating excessive gas and easing constipation.
8)Most importantly it acts as a distress tool, keeping your mind free and peaceful.
pose_precautions:
1) Avoid straining the body beyond the limits as it may cause back pain or injury.
2) Avoid practicing this asana during periods or at least during the first two days of every month’s menstrual cycle.
3) People suffering from any of this condition should avoid practicing this asana: High or low blood pressure, ulcer, joint pain, migraine, insomnia, heart disease, asthma or spinal disorders.

pose_description: Sukhasna is a comfortable position for pranayama and meditation. It gives the practitioner a centering effect. All the other asnas are done to eventually make the body feel comfortable to be able to sit in this position for meditation. This asna takes the yoga practice beyond its physical dimension and helps you get in touch with your spiritual side.
pose_steps:
1) Sit comfortably on the mat with crossed legs (left leg tugged inside the right thigh and right leg tugged inside the left thigh). 
2) Keep spine straight. 
3) Place your hands on your knees. 
4) You can use the Jnana mudra or Chin mudra. 
5) Relax your body and breathe gently.
pose_benefits:
1) Gradually strengthens muscles of the back and improves body posture.
2 Being a meditative pose it has relaxing effects on mind and body.
3) Works as a preparatory pose for more difficult meditative poses.
4) Builds physical and mental balance.
5) Helpful in reducing stress and anxiety.
6) Excellent for people having a stiff body.
7) Creates flexibility in ankle, knee and hip joints.
8)Improves concentration for achieving an effective meditation practice.
pose_precautions: 1) Avoid practicing Easy Pose in case of severe knee pain, lower backache or sciatica.

pose_description: Downward-Facing Dog is the bread and butter of yoga, but it can be challenging for beginners.This modification shares the same benefits as the classic pose — stretching the hamstrings, opening the shoulders, and creating length in the spine — without all the weight on your upper body.
pose_steps:
1) Place your hands on the back of a chair with palms shoulder-distance apart. 
2) Step your feet back until they align under hips, creating a right angle with your body, spine parallel with the floor.
pose_benefits: It stretches your shoulders and spine.It fortifies the body.It makes your spine flexible.It reduces the symptoms of chronic stress, insomnia and tension.Stretches and strengthens your hips, upper back and armsIt calms the mind and helps to relieve in stress.
pose_precautions:
1) In case of knee injuries or leg injuries don’t perform this Pose. 
2) First of all master in basic Asana then go for next level. 
3) Benefits are relying on the daily basis of your practice. 
4) Keep smiling while you perform Asana, stretch or bend as much as you can. 
5) If you feel uncomfortable in any asana during holding then release the pose. 
6) Always consult an expert person and doctor also before starting any Asana and Pranayama.

pose_description: You’ll give your inner thighs and groin a nice stretch, while the forward bend creates a calming, cooling effect.
pose_steps:
1) Sitting on the floor, bend knees and open them out to the side like a book. 
2) Join the soles of your feet together while sitting upright. 
3) Place fingertips on the floor directly behind you and lengthen up through the spine. 
4) You can also hold onto your ankles and hinge forward at the hips.
pose_benefits:
1) It stretches groin and inner thighs.
2) Increases the flexibility of knees, ankles, feet and hips.
3) Opens pelvic region.
4) Best prenatal exercise and relieves in menstrual issues.
5) Especially beneficial in urinary disorders.
6) Cut down the tension from the groin part and gap up the hips and inner thighs.
7) Beneficial for the lumbar region.
8) Useful in flat feet, high blood pressure.
9) Very beneficial in infertility and asthma.
pose_precautions:
1) Avoid this Asana if you’ve got injury within the hips, groin or knee region. 
2) You’ll use the wall for supporting the back if you are suffering from back problems.

pose_description: Considered one of the best moves for core strength, Plank Pose strengthens your abdominals and promotes stability.
pose_steps:
1) Start in Downward-Facing Dog. 
2) Shift forward so your shoulders are stacked over your wrists. 
3) Draw your navel in toward your spine and keep your hips from dropping. 
4) Reach heels back as you lengthen the crown of your head forward. 
5) Ground down into hands, pushing the floor away beneath you. 
6) Lengthen through the arms and broaden your chest.
pose_benefits:
1) Offers similar health benefits as aerobic exercise
2) Improves cardio-respiratory fitness
3) Raises endurance levels
4) Prepares the body for more challenging arm balance poses, such as side plank
5) Tones your thigh and calves
6) Improves your posture
7) Strengthens your wrists
8) Works several parts of your body, including your core, chest, low back, forearms, and shoulders
pose_precautions:
1) Do modify the pose for your comfort and skill level. 
2) You can try dolphin plank pose (forearms to the ground instead of your hands) or half plank pose (knees on the ground) instead.
3) Do learn Sun Salutation to better understand how plank pose is incorporated into this popular sequence.
4) Do open the space between your shoulder blades to deepen this posture.
5) Don’t practice the full extension of this pose if you have carpal tunnel syndrome as it places too much stress on your hands and wrists. Instead, modify the posture by resting your forearms on the floor instead of holding yourself up with your hands.
6) Don’t practice plank if you have osteoporosis as it could increase your risk of fractures.
7) Don’t allow your chest to collapse to the floor—proper posture is key to strengthening your core and back muscles.

pose_description: You’ll open up your chest and shoulders, while stretching the abdominals and hip flexors. This pose comes after chaturanga in a classic sun salutation.
pose_steps:
1) Lie facedown on the floor. 
2) Bend elbows and place hands on the mat in line with lower ribs. 
3) Hug your elbows in line with your torso. 
3) Tuck your toes and take an inhale. 
4) As you exhale, push the floor away like a push-up. 
5) Straighten your arms and broaden across the chest, hovering your hips a few inches above the floor at the same time.
pose_benefits:
1) The best exercise for your wrists.
2) Beneficial for lower back coz this pose stretches the lower back muscles.
3) Stretches the muscles of the shoulders and chest also.
4) It tones and stimulates the abdominal muscles and organs
5) It improves the posture of the body.
6) Beneficial for the chest, heart and lungs.
7) It stretches the upper back and front of your body
8) Gives strength to your shoulders, wrists, arms, and backbone.
9) Helpful in mild depression, fatigue and sciatica.

pose_precautions:

2) If you are pregnant or having problems like migraine or headache please avoid this pose.

pose_description: This balancing pose strengthens your legs and outer hips. It also stretches your hamstrings and inner thighs, and promotes concentration.
pose_steps:
1) Start in a Triangle Pose. 
2) Bend your front knee, keep it in line with your second toe. 
3) Step back foot in and walk front hand about 12 inches forward. 
4) Keep it on the floor or place it onto a block. 
5) Shift your weight onto your front foot and lift your back foot off the ground. 
6) Straighten out the front leg, keeping your front hand on the floor or on a block.Reach your back leg toward the wall behind you, foot flexed. 
7) Lift your back arm up toward the sky. 
8) Keep your gaze on the hand touching the ground.
pose_benefits:
1) This yoga posture helps in improving balance of the body and increases awareness. The person becomes aware of their body.
2) It strengthens the hamstrings, thighs and the ankles.
3) Keeps the thighbones strong while helping to get rid of back pain.

6) Balance and coordination get improved to a great extent with the regular practice of this asana.
pose_precautions:

pose_description: This pose helps build strength in your upper body in preparation for a headstand and forearm stand. It can also help calm your mind and relieve stress.
pose_steps:
1) From all fours, come down onto your forearms. 
2) Spread your fingers wide and keep elbows shoulder-width apart. 
3) On an inhale, tuck your toes and lift your hips up and back like you’re in Downward-Facing Dog. 
4) Allow your head to hang above the floor.
5) Ground down into your forearms and lift your upper body away from the floor. 
6) Press your heels down toward the mat for a nice hamstring stretch.
pose_benefits:
1) This posture is a boost for the upper body, include strengthening the Back, 
2) Abdomen, Legs, Neck, Chest, mid- and lower back, hips and hamstrings.

pose_description: This pose strengthens your shoulders, upper back, and abdominals. It also promotes core and scapular stability, which is helpful if you’re working on inversions or arm balances.
pose_steps:
1) Start in Downward-Facing Dog. 
2) Turn onto the outer edge of your right foot, making sure that your right foot and right hand are in alignment.
3) Stack your left foot on top of your right. 
4) Lengthen through the spine through the crown of your head. 
6) Once you’re stable, lift your left hand up toward the sky.
7) Press the floor away from you with the bottom hand.
pose_benefits:
1) The practice of Vasisthasana (Side Plank Pose) is Builds arm, wrist and shoulder strength
2) Its describe as a total body pose where every muscle needs to work.

pose_precautions:
Tips

pose_description: This balancing posture stretches your hamstrings and outer hips. Twisting promotes the overall health of the spine and engages your abdominal obliques to facilitate the twist.
pose_steps:
1) From mountain pose, step your left foot back and place it flat on the floor, turned out 45 degrees. 
2) Line your feet up heel to heel, or wider for more stability and space.
3) Ground down into both feet and lift up through your thighs. 
4) Hinge forward at the hips and lengthen spine over your front thigh. 
5) Release your left hand to a block placed on the outer edge of your front foot. 
6) You can also place the block on the inside of the front foot. 
7) Rotate your torso to the right. 
8) Stretch your right arm up.
pose_benefits:
1) Tones stretches and strengthens the muscles of hamstring, thigh and
2) Massages reproductive organs and pelvic region of the body.
3) Gives an intense stretch to the spine and enhances its flexibility. Strengthens spinal nerves.
4) Removes the stiffness of neck and Beneficial in correcting the misalignment of the shoulders.
5) Directs the blood flow in the lower region of the spine improving its functioning.
6) Revitalize abdominal organs hence helpful in getting rid of digestive problems and constipation.
7) Helpful in getting rid of anxiety as it stimulates the whole functioning of the nervous system.
pose_precautions:
1) If you are new to this pose, keep the head in the neutral position instead of upward.
2) Avoid practicing this asana in case of severe pain in the neck, back or shoulders.

pose_description: Crow Pose builds (and requires) serious strength in your arms, wrists, core, and hip flexors.
pose_steps:
1) Start in Mountain Pose. 
2) Come down to a deep squat, with your feet a few inches apart and your heels lifted off the mat. 
3) Make your knees wider than your hips. 
4) Bring your palms down in front of you between your knees, shoulder-width apart. 
5) Hook your shins around your upper arms.
6) Look forward, shift your weight forward onto your hands, and lift your feet off the floor. 
7) Pull up through your arms and abs, and round your upper back. \8) If you can, bring your toes to touch beneath your tailbone.
pose_benefits:
1) Strengthens wrists, arms, abdomen and shoulders.
2)Originates a sense of physical balance and coordination.
3) Balances nervous system and strengthens the core.
pose_precautions:
1) Don’t raise the buttocks too high as that put excessive stress on the arms. 
2) Don’t try to jump your feet off the floor. 
3) First, you need to transfer all your weight on your arms followed by lifting your feet off the ground.
4) People who suffer from any of this condition must avoid practicing Bakasana: recent wrist or shoulder injury, heart problems, carpal tunnel syndrome or cerebral thrombosis.

pose_description: This backbend opens the entire front of the body. It strengthens the muscles in your back, shoulders, and hamstrings.
pose_steps:
1) Lie faceup with knees bent, feet flat on the floor, like you’re prepping for bridge pose. 
2) Position your feet parallel to one another, hip-distance apart, with heels under the knees.
pose_benefits:
1) Stretches the chest and lungs
2) Strengthens the arms and wrists, legs, buttocks, abdomen, and spine
3) Stimulates the thyroid and pituitary
4) Increases energy and counteracts depression

pose_precautions:
1) You should not do Wheel Pose if you have had an injury or chronic problem with your knees, wrists, shoulders, neck, or back. 
2) Don't force your body into the pose before it is flexible enough to do so without straining. 
3) Bend back only as far as you can naturally. 
4) With continued practice, you will gradually build your flexibility to achieve the pose.

pose_description: This energizing inversion strengthens your shoulders, arms, and wrists. It helps to promote a sense of balance, confidence, and calm.
pose_steps:
1) Start in Downward-Facing Dog, facing the wall. 
2)  Place your hands 6 inches from the wall. 
3) Bend one knee and step the foot in toward the wall. 
4) Lift the other leg into the air. 
5) When you’re just getting used to being upside down, you may feel the most comfortable hopping off the bottom foot to kick the lifted leg up toward the wall. 
6) Others rely on core strength to bring both the legs up. 
7) Either way, bring your feet together against the wall. 
8) To come out of the pose, bend your knees and use your core to slowly draw your legs down to the ground. 
9)  After an inversion, take a few moments to readjust before returning to your practice.
pose_benefits:
1) Handstand builds strength in your shoulders, arms, and wrists. The psoas muscle also gets a workout in keeping your spine stabilized.
2) As an inversion, it sends blood to your head, which can both be energizing and conversely help to calm you. Handstand also helps you improve your sense of balance.
3) Like all poses that are difficult, it's fun to accomplish something that you doubted your ability to do.
pose_precautions:
1) Avoid Handstand and other inversions if you have any conditions for which your doctor recommends not letting your head go below the level of your heart.
2)  These often include uncontrolled high blood pressure, stroke, detached retina, glaucoma, and recent dental bone transplants. 
3) Also avoid this pose if you have an injury or chronic pain condition of your neck, shoulder, or wrist.
4) To see if your body can handle Handstand, check to ensure you can hold Downward Facing Dog and Plank Pose for more than 30 seconds without any pain or discomfort.
5) Until you are proficient with Handstand, practice it against a wall or with a friend or instructor spotting you.

pose_description: This is a deep shoulder opener, making it a great preparatory pose for backbends. As an inversion, it also helps improve circulation.
pose_steps:
1) Start on all fours, with your head facing the direction of the wall. 
2) Place your elbows on the floor and come down to your forearms, Bring them parallel to one other, shoulder-width apart. 
3) Tuck your toes, lift knees, and reach hips up and back into Dolphin Pose. 
4) Broaden across the chest and gaze at the floor between your forearms. 
5) Step one foot in a few inches. 
6) Lift the other leg up and straight back. 
7) Bend the knee of your grounded leg. 
8) Hop off that foot and send both feet up to the wall. 
9) Squeeze your inner thighs together and reach heels up toward the ceiling.
pose_benefits:
1) This pose not only strengthens your shoulders, arms, core, and back. but also it stretches your shoulders, neck, chest, and abdomen. 
2) By regular practice of Picha Mayurasana can provide an additional sense of balance and stability.
3) The brain is calmed and helps relieve anxiety and depression and concentration will improve.
4) This poses also increase in blood to the brain is also energizing.

6) Feathered Peacock Pose makes your wrists and elbows also stronger.
pose_precautions:

pose_description: Like headstand, this inversion offers numerous benefits to multiple systems in the body. It’s a cooling and energetic way to end your practice.
pose_steps:
1) Neatly stack two blankets with the folded edges aligned with the short edge of your mat. 
2) Lay on the blankets and place the tops of your shoulders 2 inches from the edge of the blankets. 
3) Rest your head on the floor, off the blanket. Place your arms at your sides. 
4) Bend your knees and bring your feet to the floor, heels near butt. 
5) As you inhale, bring your knees in toward your chest. 
6) As you exhale, straighten your legs and send them up toward the sky. 
7) Place your hands on your lower back to support your posture, fingertips pointed down toward your tail bone.

pose_description: Surya Namaskar  is a sequence of 12 powerful yoga poses. Besides being a great cardiovascular workout, Surya Namaskar is also known to have an immensely positive impact on the body and mind.
pose_steps:
1) Pranamasana (Prayer pose):- Stand at the edge of your mat, keep your feet together and balance your weight equally on both the feet. Expand your chest and relax your shoulders. As you breathe in, lift both arms up from the sides, and as you exhale, bring your palms together in front of the chest in prayer position. 
2)  Hastauttanasana (Raised arms pose):- Breathing in, lift the arms up and back, keeping the biceps close to the ears. In this pose, the effort is to stretch the whole body up from the heels to the tips of the fingers. 
3) Hastapadasana (Standing forward bend):- Breathing out, bend forward from the waist keeping the spine erect. As you exhale completely, bring the hands down to the floor beside the feet. 
4) Ashwa Sanchalanasana (Equestrian pose):- Breathing in, push your right leg back, as far back as possible. Bring the right knee to the floor and look up. 
5) Dandasana (Stick pose):- As you breathe in, take the left leg back and bring the whole body in a straight line. 
6) Ashtanga Namaskara (Salute with eight parts or points):- Gently bring your knees down to the floor and exhale. Take the hips back slightly, slide forward, rest your chest and chin on the floor. Raise your posterior a little bit. The two hands, two feet, two knees, chest and chin (eight parts of the body) should touch the floor. 
7)  Bhujangasana (Cobra pose):- Slide forward and raise the chest up into the Cobra pose. You may keep your elbows bent in this pose with the shoulders away from the ears. Look up at the ceiling. 
8) Adho Mukha Svanasana (Downward facing dog pose):- Breathing out, lift the hips and the tailbone up to bring the body into an inverted ‘V’ pose. 
9) Ashwa Sanchalanasana (Equestrian pose):- Breathing in, bring the right foot forward in between the two hands. The left knee goes down on the floor. Press the hips down and lookup. 
10) Hastapadasana (Standing forward bend):- Breathing out, bring the left foot forward. Keep the palms on the floor. You may bend the knees, if necessary. 
11) Hastauttanasana (Raised arms pose):- Breathing in, roll the spine up. Raise the hands up and bend backward a little bit, pushing the hips slightly outward. 
12) Tadasana (Mountain Pose):- As you exhale, first straighten the body, then bring the arms down. Relax in this position and observe the sensations in your body.
pose_release:
1) Complete the round by repeating the steps. 
2) Only this time, start with taking the left foot behind in step number 4 and bringing the right foot forward in step number 10. 
3) Once done, you would’ve completed one round of Surya Namaskar.
pose_benefits: 1) Helps maintain cardiovascular health,Stimulates the nervous system, strengthens the immune system, enhances cognitive functions, improves overall health, strengthens the body and relaxes the mind
pose_precautions:
1)  Heart patients should consult a doctor before starting this yoga routine. 
2) People having high blood pressure and hernia issues can avoid this sequence. 
3) Pregnant women should not practice Sun Salutation. 
4) Women must also avoid performing Surya Namaskar while on their periods.

pose_description: It is a standing yoga pose that utilizes all of the muscles in the body. Its name comes from four Sanskrit words: "Utthita" — meaning "extended" "Parsva" — meaning "side" or "flank"
pose_steps:
1) Turn to the left and extend your arms sideways to shoulder-height, palms facing down. Step your feet as wide apart as your wrists. 
2) Align your heels. 
3) Turn your right leg and foot outward 90 degrees so your toes point to the top of your mat.
pose_release:
1) To release, press firmly through your back foot. 
2) Then, exhale as you slowly come up to a standing position with your arms extended at shoulder-height. 
3) Turn your feet and body so they face the same direction, and then step your feet together.
pose_benefits:
1) Parsvakonasana relieves stiffness in the shoulders and back. 
2) It provides a deep stretch to the groins and hamstrings, and it also improves stamina. 
3) This pose strengthens the legs, knees, and ankles, while also stretching and toning the abdominal muscles.
pose_precautions:
1) Keep the neck in a neutral position if you are new to this pose else you are likely to experience a lot of stress in neck muscles. 
2) Don't put the weight completely on your legs and arms, rather try to stretch your body, distributing your weight evenly.

pose_description: Chair Pose, is a standing asana in modern yoga as exercise. It was a low squatting asana in medieval hatha yoga.
pose_steps:
1) Stand in Tadasana. Inhale and raise your arms perpendicular to the floor. 
2) Exhale and bend your knees, trying to take the thighs as nearly parallel to the floor as possible. 
3) Firm your shoulder blades against the back. 
4) Stay for 30 seconds to a minute.
pose_release:
1) To release, inhale and straighten your legs, lifting your body up through your arms. 
3) Exhale and return to Mountain Pose or continue to the next pose in the sequence.
pose_benefits:
1) Strengthens the ankles, thighs, calves, and spine. 
2) Stretches shoulders and chest. 
3) Stimulates the abdominal organs, diaphragm, and heart. 
4) Reduces flat feet.
pose_precautions:
1) This pose is not recommended if you have low blood pressure or an injury to your hips, knees, or back. 
2) Traditionally, it is avoided if you have insomnia. 
3) If you have balance problems, do this pose near a wall or chair you can touch to stabilize yourself if needed.

pose_description: It is a standing yoga pose that enhances strength, stability, and concentration. It's named after the Hindu mythological warrior, Virabhadra, an incarnation of the god Shiva.
pose_steps:
1) Stand in Tadasana (Mountain Pose. 
2)Turn your right foot slightly to the right and your left foot out to the left 90 degrees. 
3) Exhale and bend your left knee over the left ankle, so that the shin is perpendicular to the floor. 
4) Stretch the arms away from the space between the shoulder blades, parallel to the floor. 
5) Stay for 30 seconds to 1 minute. 
6) Inhale to come up. 
7) Reverse the feet and repeat for the same length of time to the left.
pose_release:
1) To release, inhale as you press down through your back foot and straighten your front leg. 
2) Lower your arms. 
3) Turn to the left, reversing the position of your feet, and repeat for the same length of time on the opposite side.
pose_benefits:
1) Stretches your hips, groins and shoulders. 
2) Opens your chest and lungs. 
3) Builds stamina and concentration. 
4) Energizes tired limbs. 
5) Stimulates your abdominal organs.
6) Helps relieve backaches. 
7) Develops balance and stability. 
8) Improves circulation and respiration.
pose_precautions: 1) Do not practice Warrior II if you have a recent hip, knee, or shoulder injury, or if you are experiencing diarrhea or high blood pressure.

pose_description: It is an inversion asana in modern yoga as exercise, often practised as part of a flowing sequence of poses, especially Surya Namaskar, the Salute to the Sun.
pose_steps:
1) Begin on your hands and knees. 
2) Stretch your elbows and relax your upper back. 
3) Spread your fingers wide and press firmly through your palms and knuckles. 
4) Exhale as you tuck your toes and lift your knees off the floor. 
5) Press the floor away from you as you lift through your pelvis.
pose_release:
1) It's fine if your legs are bent, just enjoy the juicy stretch and the feeling of creating space in the back of the body. 
2) After a few deep breaths, slowly release your knees down to the floor, untuck your toes and gently release your hips back down into Child's pose.
pose_benefits:
1) Calms the brain and helps relieve stress and mild depression. 
2) Energizes the body. 
3) Stretches the shoulders, hamstrings, calves, arches, and hands. 
4) Strengthens the arms and legs. 
5) Helps relieve the symptoms of menopause. 
6) Relieves menstrual discomfort when done with head supported. 
7) Helps prevent osteoporosis.
pose_precautions: 1) Those with stiff or weak back muscles, tight hamstrings, sciatica or knee problems will want to practice Downward Facing Dog gently, easing in and out of the pose while keeping the knees bent and back straight.

pose_description: It is a back-bending asana in modern yoga as exercise. It is commonly part of the widely-performed Surya Namaskar sequence, though the similar Bhujangasana may be used there instead.
pose_steps:
1) Start on your belly in a prone position. 
2) Bring your hands underneath your elbows, squeeze your elbows together, and draw your shoulders back. 
3) Press down into the tops of your feet and curl your chest up. 
4) Straighten your arms and lift your thighs up off the ground.
pose_release:
1) Place your hands on the floor alongside your body, next to your lower ribs. 
2) Point your fingers to the top of the mat and hug your elbows in close to your ribcage. 
3) Inhale as you press through your hands firmly into the floor. 
4) Straighten your arms, lifting your torso and your legs a few inches off the floor.
pose_benefits:
1) Improves posture. 
2)Strengthens the spine, arms, wrists. 
3) Stretches chest and lungs, shoulders, and abdomen. 
4) Firms the buttocks. 
5) Stimulates abdominal organs. 
6) Helps relieve mild depression, fatigue, and sciatica. 
7) Therapeutic for asthma.
pose_precautions:
1) The position requires a distributed balance of weight on your palms and shoulders. 
2) If you have a shoulder injury, back injury or sprained wrists, it's best to stay away from this pose. 
3) Pregnant women shouldn't attempt the position without a directive from a physician.

pose_description: Warrior 1 Pose is a standing yoga pose that helps build focus, power and stability. This foundational pose stretches the front side of the body and is great for building strength in the legs, core and back.
pose_steps:
1) Begin standing, then step your right foot forward about four feet. 
2) With your foot parallel and toes pointing to the top of the mat, bend your knee into a lunge. 
3) Squeeze your shoulder blades together and downward, and lift your chin to gaze at your hands overhead. 
4) Hold your pose and then repeat on the left side.
pose_release:
1) Press down through the outer edge of your back foot, keeping your back leg straight. 
2) Hold for up to one minute. 
3) To release the pose, press your weight through your back heel and straighten your front leg. Lower your arms.
pose_benefits:
1) Strengthens your shoulders, arms, legs, ankles and back. 
2)  Opens yours hips, chest and lungs. 
3) Improves focus, balance and stability. 
4) Encourages good circulation and respiration. 
5) Stretches your arms, legs, shoulders, neck, belly, groins and ankles. 
6) Energizes the entire body.
pose_precautions:
1) Avoiding this pose if you suffer from high blood pressure and heart problems. 
2) Students with problems to the shoulders should keep their raised arms either parallel or a little wider than parallel to each other.

other_names: The Rag Doll Pose, Dangling pose
pose_description: Ragdoll pose is a basic standing forward bend yoga posture that stretches the lower back.
pose_steps:
1) From a Standing Forward Bend (Uttānāsana), separate your feet hip-width apart and catch opposite elbows. 
2) Take a generous bend in your knees if you'd like, to allow your chest and thighs to connect. 
3) Shift some weight forward into the balls of your feet to send your sit bones up.
pose_release: 1) To come out of the pose, bring your hands to your hips, keep the micro-bend in your knees and come up to standing with a flat back—engaging your core to support your lower back.
pose_benefits:
1) Stretches the ankles, calves, hamstrings and lower back. 
2) Releases tension in the neck and shoulders. 
3) Can help to alleviate lower back and neck pain. 
4) Relieves stress.
pose_precautions: 1) Women who are pregnant should avoid the practice of this pose.

pose_description: It is a restorative pose. In this position, the hips flex, stretching the adductor muscles along the inside of your thighs. The upper body, including the arms shoulders and back, works to connect the hands to the feet and maintain a long spine.
pose_steps:
1) Sit on the floor on a yoga mat or a well carpeted area. 
2) Straighten your spine with legs straightened out. 
3) Bend both knees to form a winged butterfly pose. 
4) Bring your feet towards your pelvis as close as you can and join them, holding with your hands.
pose_benefits:
1) The butterfly pose renders a great stretch for the inner thighs and groin. 
2) It improves blood circulation in the lower body that is stalled due to long sitting hours. 
3) It provides relief from menstrual discomfort and issues due to menopause. 
4) Maintains healthy bowels movement.
pose_precautions:
1) People who have knee injury should not practise this asana. 
2) If you have a groin injury you should not practise this asana. 
3) Make sure that your spine is erect while performing this asana.

pose_description: It is an excellent stretch to relieve tight hamstrings, the muscles in the back of your thighs. If you tend to dislike doing a seated forward bend with both legs straight, this pose may come as a pleasant surprise.
pose_steps:
1) Sit with the legs outstretched in front of you (Staff Pose / Dandasana). 
2) Bend your right knee and place the right foot against the left inner thigh, relaxing the knee down. 
3) As you inhale, flex the left foot, press the top of the thigh down, lengthen the spine and raise your arms either side of your head.
pose_benefits:
1) Calms the brain and helps relieve mild depression. 
2) Stretches the spine, shoulders, hamstrings, and groins. 
3) Stimulates the liver and kidneys. 
4) Improves digestion. 
5) Helps relieve the symptoms of menopause. 
6) Relieves anxiety, fatigue, headache, menstrual discomfort.
pose_precautions:
1) Lengthen forward into a comfortable stretch. The lower belly should touch the thighs first, the head last. 
2) Stay in the pose anywhere from 1 to 3 minutes. 
3) Come up with an inhalation and repeat the instructions with the legs reversed for the same length of time.

pose_description: It is an asana in hatha yoga and modern yoga as exercise, often used for relaxation at the end of a session. It is the usual pose for the practice of yoga nidra meditation.
pose_steps:
1) Lie on your back with your legs straight and arms relaxed at your sides. 
2) Let your feet fall to a natural position and rest your palms facing up. 
3) Close down your eyes. 
4) Breathe naturally. 
5) Allow your body to feel heavy on the ground. 
6) Begin to release each part of your body, organ and cell, consciously working from the soles of your feet to the crown of your head. 
7) Relax your face, feeling your eyes drop into your sockets and the softening of your jaw. Tune in. 
8) If your mind starts to wander, bring your awareness to the sounds around you and then try to find the most distant sound until you find the sound closest to you. 
9) Then tune into your breath. 
10) Once we acknowledge the sounds from outside, the mind is more able to let go. 
11) To exit the pose, gently bring your awareness back to your body. 
12) Start to wriggle your fingers and toes. 
13) With your eyes closed, draw your knees in and slowly roll over to your left or right side. 
14) Rest there for a moment and with an inhale, find a comfortable seated position. 
15) Take the peace and stillness found in this pose with you for the rest of your day.
pose_benefits:
1) Calms the brain and helps relieve stress and mild depression. 
2) Relaxes the body. 
3) Reduces headache, fatigue, and insomnia. 
4) Helps to lower blood pressure.
pose_precautions:
1) Avoid moving your body while performing Savasana as it might disturb the practice and will fuel your distractions. 
3) Make sure to perform it on a hard, flat surface. 
4) Practice this in an environment that offers quiet and relaxing surroundings.

other_names: Reclined Hand to Big Toe Pose
pose_description: Reclining Hand to Big Toe pose, or Supine Hand to Toe pose is a reclining asana in modern yoga as exercise.
pose_steps:
1) Hug the thigh to your belly. 
2) Press the front of the right thigh heavily to the floor, and push actively through the right heel. 
3) Loop a strap around the arch of the left foot and hold the strap in both hands. 
4) Inhale and straighten the knee, pressing the left heel up toward the ceiling.
pose_benefits:
1) Reclining Hand-to-Big-Toe Pose offers a stretch to the hips, thighs, hamstrings, and calves, and strengthens the muscles around the knees. 
2) The pose also improves digestion, and can help to relieve lower back pain.
pose_precautions:
1) Don't flatten your lumbar curve or press your lower spine into the mat. 
2) Doing so reduces the stretch in your hamstrings and may cause a flattening of your lumbar spine over time, which is unhealthy for your lower back. 
3) Don't perform the pose with your top leg bent, which minimizes the stretch in your hamstring.

pose_description: It is a supine (lying-down) yoga pose that relieves stiffness in the outer hips and lower back. If you spend a lot of time sitting, those muscles become tight and short due to the lack of use. This pose can feel great at the end of a long day of sitting at work, school, or in a car or airplane.
pose_steps:
1) Hug your left knee into your chest. 
2) Cross the left ankle over your body and rest it on the right thigh. 
3) Let the left knee relax away from your torso. 
4) Lift your right foot off the floor and thread your left hand through your legs (this is the eye of the needle) so your hands meet on the back side of your right thigh.
pose_benefits:
1) This pose stretches the muscles around the hips, the lower back, and the hamstrings at the back of the thighs. 
2) Hip flexors often become tight when you sit for long periods, while the hamstrings are often tight on runners and those in sports that do a lot of running.
pose_precautions:
1) Avoid this pose if you have any shoulder, neck, knee, back, or hip problem. 
2) After the first trimester, pregnant women should avoid poses where you are flat on your back. 
3) You should not feel any stress on the knee. 
4) You will feel a great stretch along the front of the hip, but it should not be painful.

pose_description: It is a dynamic standing yoga pose that utilizes and integrates the muscles in your entire body. It stretches and strengthens the lower and upper body, while creating stability and balance.
pose_steps:
1) Bring your hands onto your right knee and your right knee directly over your right ankle. 
2) Inhale and raise your arms above your head, keeping the arms in line with your ears. 
3) Exhale and deepen forward into the lunge, bending the right knee more if possible. 
4) As you do, your left hip comes closer to the floor.
pose_release:
1) Bring your hands onto your right knee and your right knee directly over your right ankle. 
2) Inhale and raise your arms above your head, keeping the arms in line with your ears. 
3) Exhale and deepen forward into the lunge, bending the right knee more if possible. 
4) As you do, your left hip comes closer to the floor.
pose_benefits:
1) Crescent Lunge Pose stretches the hip flexors and quadriceps. 
2) This is useful for cyclists and for those who sit much of the day. 
3) It also opens the chest, shoulders, and torso. 
4) You can practice it to build your balance and stability.
pose_precautions:
1) Be sure not to deepen the front knee quickly, and listen to your body as you move. 
2) If you notice any discomfort in that knee, be sure to stop and back off to avoid further pain and possible injury. 
3) Keep the back foot straight—do not let it sneak inward.

pose_description: It is translated as Intense Side Stretch from Sanskrit. ... The name of this pose comes from parsva meaning side, ut meaning intense , and tan meaning to stretch, and asana meaning posture or seat.
pose_steps:
1) Press your weight evenly through the outer edge of your back foot and the big toe of your front foot. 
2) Draw your left hip slightly forward, squaring your hips to the top of the mat. 
3) Draw your shoulder blades firmly into your back, but do not let your low ribs puff forward. 
4) Inhale as you reach your arms out to the sides.
pose_release:
1) To release, press firmly through your back heel and slowly lift your torso. 
2) Release your arms and place your hands on your hips. 
3) Change the position of your feet, and repeat on the opposite side.
pose_benefits:
1) Calm the brain and flush the sinuses with mild inversion. 
2) Stretch the spine. 
3) Strengthen the legs and spine. 
4) Improve posture. 
5) Aid digestion. 
6) Elongate hamstrings.
pose_precautions:
1) Avoid this pose if you have any injury or condition affecting your hamstrings, hips, back, shoulders, or wrists. 
2) Because of the deep bend, you should avoid it if you have high blood pressure, heart disease, glaucoma, or are pregnant (especially in the third trimester).

pose_description: It is used for a different squatting pose with the feet together and the back rounded with multiple hand placement variations.
pose_steps:
1) Squat with your feet as close together as possible. 
2)Separate your thighs slightly wider than your torso. 
3) Press your elbows against your inner knees, bringing your palms to together in Anjali Mudra (Salutation Seal), and resist the knees into the elbows. 
4) To go further, press your inner thighs against the sides of your torso. 
5) Reach your arms forward, then swing them out to the sides and notch your shins into your armpits. 
6) Press your finger tips to the floor, or reach around the outside of your ankles and clasp your back heels. 
7) Hold the position for 30 seconds to 1 minute, then inhale, straighten the knees, and stand into Uttanasana.
pose_benefits:
1) Opens your hips and groin. 
2) Stretches your ankles, lower hamstrings, back and neck. 
3) Tones your abdominals. 
4) Aids in digestion. 
5) Strengthens your metabolism. 
6) Keeps your pelvic and hip joints healthy. 
7) Ideal for prenatal yoga.
pose_precautions:
1) Avoid Garland Pose if you have a knee or low back injury. 
2) Be sure to avoid any jerky motion or coming down into your squat forcefully. 
3) Don't push yourself into a deeper squat than your body is ready to achieve. 
4) If you feel any pain, back out of the pose. 
5) Practice this pose only on an empty stomach. 
6) Do not put the pressure on your heel during practicing it.

pose_description: It is a backbending asana in hatha yoga and modern yoga as exercise.
pose_steps:
1) First of all lie down in prone position. Exhale, bend your knees and hold the ankles with hands. 
2) While inhaling raise the thighs, head and chest as high as possible. 
3) Try to maintain weight of the body on lower abdomen. Join the ankles. 
4) While exhaling, bring down the head and legs up to knee joint.
pose_release:
1) Be sure to release the pose once you've lowered your head, chest, thighs, and feet. 
2) Releasing the pose when these body parts are lifted can cause a painful impact on the floor. 
3) Lower yourself slowly and then release your ankles when you can do so safely.
pose_benefits:
1) Stretches the entire front of the body, ankles, thighs and groins, abdomen and chest, and throat, and deep hip flexors (psoas) 
2) Strengthens the back muscles. 
3) Improves posture. 
4) Stimulates the organs of the abdomen and neck.
pose_precautions: 1) This pose should be avoided if you are pregnant, have high blood pressure, a neck injury, pain in the lower back, hernia, migraine, heart disease, and/or had recent abdominal surgery.

pose_description: It is a standing asana in modern yoga as exercise. It was a low squatting asana in medieval hatha yoga.
pose_steps:
1) Bend your knees and bring your thighs as parallel to the floor as possible. 
2) Your knees should come out over your feet and your torso should lean forward over the thighs, more or less forming a right angle with them. 
3) Keep your back long, with a slight curve in it, and keep the inner thighs parallel to each other.
pose_release:
1) To release from the pose, straighten the knees with an inhalation while lifting strongly through the arms. 
2) Straighten out completely and allow your arms to remain loosely by your sides. 
3) Exhale out completely and come to stand in Tadasana.
pose_benefits:
1) Strengthen your legs (ankles, thighs, calves). 
2) Stretch your shoulders, chest and spine. 
3) Stimulate the abdominal region.
pose_precautions:
1) Inhale and Exhale: Begin to inhale and exhale while in the pose. 
2) With every inhalation, loosen the body, and with every exhalation take the tail bone out, pushing the hips down and stretching the arms out to the maximum. Inhale: Bring the arms down releasing from the pose.

pose_description: Also known as Reclined Cobbler's Pose, is a deeply relaxing yoga position that is recommended for students of all levels. Its Sanskrit name — “Supta Baddha Konasana” (SOOP-tah BAH-duh cone-AHS-uh-nuh) — comes from four words: “Supta” — meaning “reclining”
pose_steps:
1) Begin seated in Staff Pose (Dandasana), with your legs extended in front of you on the mat. 
2) Bend your knees and draw your heels in toward your pelvis. 
3)Press the soles of your feet together and let your knees drop open to both sides. 
4) This is Bound Angle (or Cobbler's) Pose (Baddha Konasana).
pose_release:
1) To come out of the pose, take the palms of the hands on the outer thighs to gently fold the legs together, and bring the soles of the feet flat down on the mat. 
2) Then, hug your knees into your chest and gently rock from side to side to release the low back.
pose_benefits:
1) Stimulates abdominal organs like the ovaries and prostate gland, bladder, and kidneys. 
2) Stimulates the heart and improves general circulation. 
3) Stretches the inner thighs, groins, and knees. 
4) Helps relieve the symptoms of stress, mild depression, menstruation and menopause.
pose_precautions:
1) Avoid practicing SuptaBaddhaKonasana if you're suffering from following problems: Shoulder injury, groin injury, knee injury, hip injury. 
2) If you suffer from lower back pain then do not practice it.

pose_description: It is a static plié squat, and is a major external hip opener that fires everything below your waist! Goddess Pose lengthens the adductors of your inner thighs and strengthens your calves, quadriceps, glutes, and core — and it doesn't ignore your upper body.
pose_steps:
1) Begin standing in Mountain Pose (Tadasana) at the top of your mat with your arms at your sides. 
2) Turn to the right and step your feet wide apart, about four feet. 
3) On an exhalation, bend your knees directly over your toes and lower your hips into a squat.
pose_benefits:
1) Opens the hips, legs, and chest. 
2) Strengthens the legs, calves, abs, and knees. 
3) Stimulates the uro-genital system and pelvic floor. 
4) Strengthens and stretches the shoulder joint.
pose_precautions: 1) Students recovering from shoulders, rib cage, hips, pelvis, knees, ankles and toes injuries should avoid the practice of Goddess Pose.

pose_description: The twist also helps reduce belly fat. It increases the elasticity of the spine and relieves vertebrae stiffness.
pose_steps:
1) Bring your left hand to the outside of your right knee, exhaling as you gently twist to the right. 
2) Inhale again as you lengthen your spine, and exhale as you twist deeper. 
3) Gaze over your right shoulder. 
4) Do not push hard against your knee to force a deeper twist.
pose_benefits:
1) It stretches the back muscles and glutes. 
2)  It massages the back and hips. 
3) It helps to hydrate the spinal disks. 
4) It lengthens, relaxes, and realigns the spine. 
5) It massages the abdominal organs and strengthens the abdominal muscles.
pose_precautions:
1) Avoid this asana if you have ulcers, slipped disc, or severe spine, shoulder, or hip injury. 
2) Also, as a closed twist, women who are pregnant should avoid this pose.

pose_description: Viparita Karani or legs up the wall pose is both an asana and a mudra in hatha yoga. In modern yoga as exercise, it is commonly a fully supported pose using a wall and sometimes a pile of blankets.
pose_steps:
1) If you are practicing the supported version, set a bolster or firm, long pillow on the floor against the wall. 
2) Begin the pose by sitting with your left side against the wall. 
3) Gently turn your body to the left and bring your legs up onto the wall. 
4) Lower your back to the floor and lie down. 
5) Shift your weight from side-to-side and scoot your buttocks close to the wall. 
6) Let your arms rest open at your sides, palms facing up. 
7) If you’re using a bolster, your lower back should now be fully supported by it. 
8) Let the heads of your thigh bones (the part of the bone that connects in the hip socket) release and relax, dropping toward the back of your pelvis. 
9) Close your eyes. Hold for 5-10 minutes, breathing with awareness.
pose_release:
1) To release, slowly push yourself away from the wall and slide your legs down to the right side. 
2) Use your hands to help press yourself back up into a seated position.
pose_benefits:
1)Strengthened immune system. 
2) Balanced hormonal system. 
3) Calmed nervous system. 
4) Stabilized digestive and elimination systems. 
5) Regulated respiratory system.
pose_precautions:
1) Check with your teacher before performing this pose during menstruation. 
2) As with any inversion Viparita Karani should be avoided if you have serious eye problems, such as glaucoma. 
3) With serious neck or back problems only perform this pose with the supervision of an experienced teacher.

pose_description: Garudasana or Eagle Pose is a standing balancing asana in modern yoga as exercise. The name was used in medieval hatha yoga for a different pose.
pose_steps:
1) Bend your knees slightly, lift your left foot up and, balancing on your right foot, cross your left thigh over the right. 
2) Point your left toes toward the floor, press the foot back, and then hook the top of the foot behind the lower right calf. 
3) Balance on the right foot.
pose_release:
1) To release, inhale and uncross your arms and legs. 
2) Left both arms up toward the ceiling and place both feet back on the floor.
pose_benefits:
1) Stronger arms, legs, knees and ankles. 
2) Open shoulder joints, creating space between the shoulder blades. 
3) Open hips and IT band. 
4) Increased circulation to all joints. 
5) Improved digestion and elimination. 
6) Improved balance. 
7) Improved focus.
pose_precautions:
1) Avoid practicing Garudasana in case you have had a recent knee, ankle or shoulder injury. 
2) Eagle pose should not be attempted if you suffer from any of these conditions: Obesity, frequent headaches, high or low blood pressure or asthma.

pose_description: It's a beautiful marriage of strength, flexibility, balance, and meditation. Kinda like the asana jackpot in my mind. It tones and strengthens the leg muscles, stretches and opens the shoulders and chest, improves balance, and focuses the mind.
pose_steps:
1) Begin by standing tall in Mountain Pose (Tadasana) with your weight equally distributed in both feet. 
2) Shift your weight onto the right foot. 
3) Bend your left knee to lift your left foot off the floor. 
4) Keep your left knee hugging toward your midline throughout this pose.
pose_release:
1) Stay for 5-10 breaths. 
2) To come out of the pose, release the leg as you exhale.
pose_benefits:
1) Natarajasana requires and builds full-body strength, flexibility, and coordination. 
2) It opens the shoulders, chest, and hips, as it stretches and strengthens the thighs, ankles, and abdomen. 
3)This pose develops greater flexibility in your spine, shoulders, and hamstrings.
pose_precautions:
1) Low blood pressure: Don't do this yoga if you are having low blood pressure. 
2) Balancing: Performing this yoga, balancing is utmost important. 
3) It is better if one practice it before a yoga expert. 
4) Avoid excessive stretching.

pose_description: Crocodile Pose (Makarasana) is a beginner yoga pose that relaxes the whole body and helps relieve pain related to other yoga poses or other activities. By lying on your stomach with your chest and shoulders rest, you let go of tension in the lower back and open up your chest and shoulders.
pose_steps:
1) Bend your knees so your feet come closer to the center. 
2) Reach your arms back and grasp your ankles. 
3) Slowly lift so your chest and legs are off the yoga mat. 
4) You will feel this pose in your lower back, but it will also open your chest and shoulders like Crocodile Pose.
pose_release:
1) Slowly bring the feet together. 
2) Unfold the arms and come to the Prone Position.
pose_benefits:
1) It is excellent for people suffering from spondylitis, slipped disc or spinal disorders. 
2) Crocodile pose reduces stress and tension, promotes sleep. 
3) Regulates blood pressure and reduces anxiety. 
4) It gives deep relaxation to the shoulders and the spine.
pose_precautions:
1) Avoid moving the body in this asana as it may disturb the practice. 
2) Don't put stress on the body during this asana as it is all about peacefully relaxing the body. 
3) Avoid practicing this asana in the disturbing atmosphere as it may disturb the peace of mind.

pose_description: It is an easy exercise often done in Pilates and yoga classes. It is a gentle stretch for the hamstrings, inner thigh, and inner groin, a relaxation exercise for the back, and it also opens up the hips, shoulders, and chest. Happy Baby is a nice treat to give yourself any time.
pose_steps:
1) Open your knees slightly wider than your torso, then bring them up toward your armpits. 
2) Position each ankle directly over the knee, so your shins are perpendicular to the floor. 
3) Flex through the heels. 
4) Gently push your feet up into your hands (or the belts) as you pull your hands down to create a resistance.
pose_release: 1) Exhale and release the feet back to the floor.
pose_benefits:
1) Releases lower back and sacrum. 
2) Opens hips, inner thighs, and groin. 
3) Stretches the hamstrings. 
4) Relieves lower back pain. 
5) Stretches and soothes the spine. 
6) Calms the brain. 
7) Helps relieve stress and fatigue.
pose_precautions:
1) When doing Happy Baby or Dead Bug, especially if you suffer from a prior knee or neck injury. 
2) A prop, such as a folded blanket, may be used to support the neck while in this pose.

pose_description: The forearm plank is a static core exercise similar to holding the top of a push-up, with both the elbows and hands making contact with the floor. The pose engages multiple muscle groups at once, simultaneously building core, back, leg and arm strength.
pose_steps:
1) Assume a push-up position but bend your arms at your elbows so your weight rests on your forearms. 
2) Tighten your abs, clench your glutes and keep your body straight from head to heels. 
3) Hold as long as you can.
pose_release: 1) Release from Catur Svanasana, and as you exhale go lower with the body closer to the floor while supporting the body on the elbows.
pose_benefits:
1) Although it's tough, when done correctly, the Forearm Plank strengthens the abs, legs and core. 
2) It is also good for stretching the arches of your feet as well as your calves, shoulders and hamstrings.
pose_precautions:
1) The body should not arch or sag. 
2) Mostly the Plank targets the abdominals (muscles responsible for holding in the stomach and giving the appearance of a flat stomach), but it can be an excellent way to get a full body challenge.

pose_description: Kapotasana or Pigeon Pose is a kneeling back-bending asana in modern yoga as exercise.
pose_steps:
1) Sit with your knees bent, feet flat on the floor, arms behind you for support. 
2) Bring your right ankle over your left knee, keeping the foot flex. 
3) Walk your left foot closer to your hip to increase the stretch. 
4) You can also do Figure four lying on your back.
pose_benefits:
1) Stimulate the internal organs. 
2) Stretch deep glutes. 
3) Stretch groins and psoas (a long muscle on the side of your vertebral column and pelvis). 
4) Relieve impinged piriformis and alleviate sciatic pain. 
5) Help with urinary disorders.
pose_precautions:
1) In case of sacroiliac injury do not practice this posture. 
2) If you have ankle or knee injury, avoid this posture. 
3) Recent or chronic back injury is contraindication for that posture.

pose_description: Dands are jackknifing push-ups and bethaks are comparable to Western-style deep knee bends. Although dands and bethaks are done separately, they are usually referred to as a pair. As a set they provide a complete body workout. ... They should sway with the movement of the body in order to maintain balance.
pose_steps:
1) One starts a dand from a face-down, prone position with feet placed close together and palms flat on the ground directly below the shoulders about half a meter apart. 
2) To begin, one cocks the body back by lifting one's buttocks into the air while straightening both arms and legs
pose_benefits:
1) Gaining weight. 
2) Making the body stronger and build muscles. 
3) It also increases stamina.
